title: BB-8, you're no R2-D2!
text: Amazon is about the only place I've seen candid accurate reviews of this BB-8. For the price this is a poor product designed in a short timeframe and rushed to market.  The only function that really works well is "Drive".  Other features like "Patrol" I would expect BB-8 to learn where objects are when it hits them. But it doesn't it just keeps running into them time after time. Some of the voice commands like go explore or look around hardly do anything. The R2-D2 interactive Astromech droid I've had for 10 years which has infrared and sound sensors is much more intelligent than this droid.  Online there is a BB-8 Users Manual but it offers no detail for any of the functions. Maybe with future firmware and app software updates this can be made to be a good product but at this point I'm going to return it while I still can. Perhaps I will have A New Hope when there is another thats more capable than this initial release version.

title: Be aware of what it really does
text:
Not sure why people are giving a product that did not deliver on its promises 5 stars, but it is not a 5 star product, especially not for the price.
I won't waste too much time repeating what some of the top reviews said, but main point is do not listen to the product video, it can't really do any of that stuff. It is a very misleading video. It does not learn your room, it just randomly bumps into things and goes in another direction to come back and bump into the same stuff again.
I like some things about it, but I would have like to make the decision to buy this based on actual functions of the device, not misled and flat out lied to by the company to buy this on false pretenses.

title: Not your typical remote control toy
text: Probably the best remote control toy I've ever seen in my life and I've owned my share as have my sons. You can't help but love BB8 in Star Wars. It may not be human, but it had manners to make you smile. This one does the same thing. And because it uses an app for the remote control piece, it does so much more. It can show you a hologram that you view through the app. You can give it voice commands or use the app to move it around. Don't think my son will get tired of this one quickly.

title: Interesting toy but has some flaws and drawbacks to consider
text:
Bought this for grandchildren and think they will have fun with it. Reason for three stars is that I find on thick pile or even some thin carpets that it slows to a crawl if it moves at all. I have wall to wall carpeting with orientals and it has trouble climbing from the wall to wall onto an oriental. But on hardwood or other had flooring it is a speedy little droid. No instructions come with the droid other than pictures that do not tell you much. You can go on their site and click on links and only then will you find some useful information e.g., that you are supposed to set it on hard surface and attach head until magnets find it, that you need a full charge before first use, that it has a lithium battery so unlike NiCad does not need to be drained before recharging. That there is a reset button the side of the base. Have not had to use it but only found reference to that in comments under their link, not in link itself. That the charge to play ratio is 3:1 e.g., 3 hours of charging to 1 hour of play. The user manual unfortunately is filled with little but warnings and cautions and while that is useful an operating manual would be very helpful. I am still not sure I have found all the features. Sent an e mail to support about this and got no response other than an e mail telling me issue was solved! Not terribly supportive! I printed out the page from the links on their support page on the voice commands but an operating manual with all these that you could print would be a big help. Obviously you cannot be looking at their links at the same time you are operating the droid. Some have pointed out that it is small but I have no problem with that. Younger children will find easier to handle and on hard floors it does run like crazy. Wondered what my dog, a Jack Russell, would think of it but he tends to ignore it. Watches it go by but does not find interesting enough to chase. More curious than anything but leaves it alone. Have not had problem of head falling off that others have mentioned but can see if hit a wall or table leg at top speed how that could happen. I agree with comments that camera on the droid would have been nice feature but I do not find the fact that sound is on the app device bothers me. The hologram feature is interesting but limited in the built in features. I agree with those commenting that it does not seem to have any learning or adaptive features; if so I have not found them. True it will change directions if runs into an obstacle but it does not seem to learn anything in the process. Not sure what they are talking about when they say it learns and adapts. On the whole it is a fun toy even though pricey. Will be interested to see how my grandchildren like it and whether it is something they will play with or tire of it quickly. They say they will be adding features and will look forward to those upgrades.

Added post Christmas. Gave this item to my adult son for Christmas to play with his young daughters. Found that they have added some added features. Before the only hologram was a figure but now they have added a starfighter. Of course you can add your own. Also they have added several new features in the drive setting. Wish they had BB-8 talking or making sounds more than it does. Know some are bothered by sounds not coming from BB-8 but the device used to control it but while that would be nice it does not bother me. The adults had fun playing with it and grandkids enjoyed watching and eventually they will learn to use it as well. Dogs (more than one at Christmas) just ignored it which is probably good! I was bit concerned that for the price this would be a one hour wonder. Fun for first hour and then put away. But that was not the case so far. As for size we all liked the smaller size. One thing we did find that it was easiest to wake up BB-8 either on its stand or on a table. Putting on floor you have to bend over too long for it to initialize. You have to hold the control app close to BB-8 to get it started. Once it is wake and ready to go putting on floor then works fine. As noted above works best on hardwood or other hard flooring and on some of my thicker carpets it would not go at all.

Because of the fun my son and my daughter's boyfriend had with this at Christmas I am raising my stars from 3 to 4. Reason for only four is that support needs to be better and they need an operating manual although perhaps until they finish adding features you would have to update that but even an operating manual now with occasional supplement and revision would be helpful. Not all the features are intuitive or covered on their site. And using your app device to control it you cannot be going back and forth to the links for information if needed. Plus not everything is included there.

title: Original BB-8 by Sphero (No Droid Trainer) was the center of attention at the party.
text:
I ordered this Original BB-8 by Sphero (No Droid Trainer) for my son-n-law. I was surprised to see just how small the robot was. However, at the Christmas party with no actual children in attendance. I was amazed at the attention this little guy got.

It works right out of the box. It is a good quality product. I would buy it again. I am confident in my review of 5 stars.

title: Okay if you know what you're getting
text:
I waited impatiently to get my own Sphero BB-8 App-Enabled Droid! I had watched the Sphero product videos and was amazed at what this cute little guy can do. I'm a gadget nerd and had to get my hands on this! Unfortunately, my expectations were too high.

First, let me start off by saying BB-8 is very cute. That part is true. I love the look, the design and the shiny finish. It is made of plastic, but appears to be good quality. It's very user friendly and you can be playing with BB-8 within minutes. The only set-up required is to charge BB-8 and download the app.

What can BB-8 do? Once you download the free app, you can:
"Drive" This feature of the app lets you control BB-8 as if you were using a joystick.
"Message" Record and play holographic messages.
"Patrol" When you select patrol, BB-8 goes exploring on his own.

BB-8 has the capability of responding to 10 preset voice commands by going to the settings in the app, such as "wake up", "watch out", "go explore" "go to sleep". I was expecting more than 10 voice commands. Siri has spoiled me. I have heard, but cannot verify, that the voice commands only work with iOS devices. If this is accurate, that's a huge drawback for anyone without an iPhone or iPad.

BB-8 is very cute (I know, I'm saying it again), has a great personality and is entertaining to watch as he rolls across the floor. That is about the extent of the entertainment.

I feel I was misled by the promotional videos. I was under the impression that BB-8 can "detect" when he is going to run into an object, stop himself and change directions; or, perhaps, adapt to his surroundings and learn where objects are. My impression of this came from the part in one of the promotional videos where BB-8 rolls up to a fishbowl with a goldfish in it, stops before hitting it and changes direction.

When I set BB-8 to "patrol", he wobbles around a bit, rolls quickly across the floor, hits a wall or other object, wobbles around again, rolls across the floor, hits another object, etc. It's entertaining to watch and the expressive sounds are fun, but after about 5 minutes I'm bored. The worst part of this is BB-8's head falls off frequently when running into an object so I'm constantly following him around to put it back on. Also, if you have stairs in your house as I do, watch out! BB-8 will roll right down the stairs and I'm not sure if he's sturdy enough to bounce down the stairs and land on a tile floor without breaking. I've "saved" BB-8 an untimely death a few times now. Again, this falls under my misunderstanding of thinking BB-8 will adapt to his surroundings or detect a drop off. I have a robotic vacuum that didn't cost much more than BB-8 and has that very capability. It knows to turn around to avoid crashing down the stairs. It also vacuums right up to the edge of walls and furniture, but never actually touches it. Hmmmm.......

Next is the issue with the sound. Again, my expectations being different than reality. I thought the sounds would come from BB-8, when really the sounds all come from your smartphone. Very disappointing! I'll set BB-8 on "patrol", set my smartphone down in one room and let BB-8 go explore the house. I don't get the enjoyment of hearing the sounds if I don't carry my phone with me and it's not as realistic even if your phone is right next to BB-8 because you can easily tell no sound is coming from him. This is perhaps the biggest disappointment.

Finally, the holographic messages. I thought it would be like in the movie and BB-8 would project a recorded message onto the wall or what-not and play the recorded message. The message only shows up on your smartphone. When using the app through a Motorola smartphone (and others), this feature doesn't work at all. I don't know if it's something that there will be a fix for in the future? It does work on an iPhone and other devices, but is still disappointing that BB-8 isn't really projecting anything.

This is a very expensive toy and the novelty wears off very fast, especially if you're expecting something more and it doesn't deliver. If you're a Star Wars Memorabilia collector, you've probably made up your mind and probably should purchase it. If you're like me and love Star Wars but aren't a collector and/or your a gadget nerd like me, you'll probably be disappointed. There's not much to it besides watching it roll around the floor, crashing into things.

To summarize the Pros:
Very Cute!
Realistic looking miniature version of BB-8
Great novelty item for Star Wars Collectors
Cool Gadget
Easy Set-Up
Fun Sound Effects

To summarize the Cons:
Entertainment won't last long
Doesn't detect obstacles or objects in it's way
Head falls off
Doesn't sense drops to prevent it from falling down the stairs
Sound doesn't come from droid
Holographic messages are really just a video on your smartphone ~ if your smartphone is compatible
Only 10 voice commands
Voice commands may only work with iOS devices
Price is too high for what you really get

title: Don't buy. Can't replace batteries once they die.
text:
I got this for my daughter as a gift, hoping she'd like it and get interested in STEM.

True, this thing is educational and entertaining. But the batteries are NOT replaceable. There are Youtube videos teaching you how to open this thing up, but b/c the sphere is fused together, it is near impossible. Then you'd have to get the right batteries, know how to solder batteries, and have soldering equipment at home. Basically, $150 down the drain once the batteries die. I am an electrical engineer, and the time in trying to cut this thing in half, spending $30 more in batteries, and hoping that I could get this soldered back together properly is definitely not worth my while.

There are many other educational and remote-control robots out there where the batteries are easily accessible. Please do not waste your money on this.

title: This was not the droid I was looking for....
text: This is quite fun...while it lasted.  I really enjoyed the experience of the app and playing with this droid.  I don't know that I explored all the features.  After a few weeks the app simply would not connect to BB8.  I contacted Sphero who was responsive and gave me additional troubleshooting steps.  None worked.  They suggested I return it to Amazon which I did. There was a bit of miscommunication and my refund wasn't correctly applied but Amazon later corrected it when I contacted them.  As for my BB8 experience, it was fun and I would recommend to any fan along with my story.  I think it's a bit expensive for the fun it offers though.  My kids played with it for a few weeks and then lost interest.  That's true of many toys though.  Probably better to experience someone else if you can before you buy to see if it will hold your interest.  $130 could be used for something better that will get more use (like Legos or a Kindle Paperwhite which I ended up getting for my wife).

title: Overpriced. Much much smaller than expected. Nothing life-changing.
text:
Clever and cute, but abusively priced in the classic Disney way.

The box this came in looks about the right size, I assumed this little guy could be about the size of a naval orange/soft ball and it's not... it's about 1/2 that size... it's tiny.

My first two thoughts were:

1. Why the heck was the box so big for _that_?
2. Why did I just pay $120 for _that_?

It works well with your phone (you use an app to control it) and has cute little behaviors like moving around randomly when you stop controlling it - giving it a little personality. I have NO idea if you had it on a desk if it would just scoot it's way off the edge, we have only played with it on the floor.

The head is magnetically attached - it works well - my only complaint would be that it doesn't slide across the surface of the ball super smoothly so it sort of jerks a little as the ball rolls.

Buy this because you or the person you are giving it to LOVES Star Wars/BB8/etc. - if none of those statements are true, you might feel let down.

title: It's a Star Wars Droid, of course you want one!
text:
I really enjoy my little droid.But then I am a Star Wars fanatic and a Droid fanatic so......
He does cool stuff, you can putter him around. If your looking for a Droid that can "Do Something" well then "Move Along, Move Along".
This little guys doesn't "Do" a whole lot as he comes right out of the box. You can move him around or he can move around on his own. That's about it for the average Joe. I have read articles that state as the movie release gets closer, BB-8 will get updates. Can't wait to see what he reveals.

Now for the above average Joe, there are other apps that work with BB-8 and you can even program your own movements, color changes and stuff. So he is more capable if you are more capable. Many of the Sphero compatible apps will work with BB-8.

I also want to mention that the folks that packaged this little guy must have taken lessons from Amazon. The packaging was Fantastic.

Overall I'm very pleased with the way the product looks and works. As a Star Wars collector I'm very happy that he is closely scaled correctly for my 12" figures (about 1:6 scale) so he fits well with with 3PO and R2 on my shelf.

Seriously- this was a gift and I paid a bit more for it than other sellers asked because it would arrive by Christmas. title: Awesome toy and works well. Not recommended for carpet
text:
Very cool droid. I have been playing with bb8 for a few hours now and it's a really fun toy. Controlling the droid is a little hard but it seems like it will get easier with use. Charging now so I will update the review later on.

The question about working on carpet had come up and here is the results. On thin basement like carpet BB8 will work fine but on think bedroom carpet it will not. The thick carpet causes the droid to get stuck and stop moving. I would not recommend buying this droid if you plan on using it on carpet.

Other then that the droid is a cool toy and lots of fun. Moves pretty fast on solid ground.

title: Head is a dust magnet - hard to clean
text:
These things have been mentioned elsewhere, but just in case you read my review and not the others:

Pros- very cute, responds well to the programmed voice commands, once you learn how to control it (moving the blue light towards you) it is fairly easy to maneuver

Cons- no sounds actually come from the droid-it all comes from the app, the app looks nice but can be difficult to navigate, the head falls off a lot for even minor collisions, and perhaps the thing that personally bothers me the most- even if you have clean floors, the little wheels under the head pick up small specks of dust and hair very quickly and it is VERY hard to clean and maybe impossible to completely get the funk off the head rollers because there's no way to disassemble and reassemble the head. The bad thing is that once the head rollers get gunk on them (after maybe an hour of use on a clean floor), the head movement is effected and gets very jerky.

All in all, I think it's absolutely adorable but given the cons, I would not purchase again - at least not at the $150 price.

title: Decent Toy
text: I'm not going into a lot of detail on this because I see many others already have. I didn't buy mine here because I received it as a Christmas present but I will say that this is a decent little toy that is fun to get out every now and then, especially if you're showing it to someone for the first time. It has a pretty decent range as long as it's still in view but if you end up around a corner or it if goes between you and an obstacle like a piece of furniture you'll probably have to go and get it. It performs best on flat, smooth surfaces like the hardwood floors we have but it will also work on some carpeting but at a slower speed. One issue I had was with the app not working on my Droid Turbo 2 but I have a Samsung Galaxy 3 that I use for work and the app worked fine on that one. When I used it right out of the box I put it in the charger and it "woke up" right away and worked fine. The next day it didn't respond at all even after being in the charger all night but I had some help finding info online that helped troubleshoot it and it works just fine now. It's pretty sturdy but I wouldn't recommend it for small children because it can be difficult to get the hang of. This is a good video to watch to get a little more info https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WMhWoe6OK0I but if the link is removed or not allowed just look on YouTube for Star Wars BB-8 Droid Showdown: Sphero vs Hasbro vs Disney and it's 11:02 long. Hope this info helps!

title: I want to love BB8, theres just one major flay IMO
text:
I want to love BB8 from Sphero. He is EXTREMELY well made. I love the wireless charging. When he moves, he moves very well. The only drawback is the controls through Bluetooth on a phone or tablet SUCK! There is just a delay that drives you insane when your trying to run it. If this was "fixed" it would be a way better toy. It is just very hard to control him when your trying to maneuver him around table and chair legs, or whatever the obstacle may be. I wish it would have come with its own remote control, that would have been a 5 star move in my opinion.

I don't know why all these companies are trying to have you run everything through your tablet of phone. There is just a miserable delay. Now, maybe it may be our phones and/or tablet that is just slow getting the commands to BB8? I'm not that deep of a tech guy. But if a company is going to produce an awesome toy, have it run through your phone or tablet, you shouldn't have to be a super tech nerd to make it work and/or respond fast.

But like I said, this thing is built amazing well. The box it comes in, makes you feel like your opening up something extremely special. They put a lot of thought into packaging, just wish it would have come in a normal box, with its own remote maybe?

title: Tips for Using BB-8
text:
Here are a few tips:
1) make sure it is fully charged as usual with these devices. It should have maybe a 3/4 charge when you get it. But when it runs out, it can sometimes take a few hours to get back to a full charge.
2) Blinking blue light means it is charging, solid blue means it is ready.
3) use it on hard floors. Doesnâ€™t work as well on thick carpet.
4) For fun if you have kids... after you install the app, read the instructions and learn how to get BB-8 to answer â€œyesâ€ or â€œnoâ€. Let the kids ask it questions while you answer without them knowing. This provided about 30 min of fun and laughter for the young ones. Then once the gig was up, they took control and started doing it with their friends.
5) Donâ€™t skip the hologram mode. That was surprisingly cool.

Hope you enjoy!

title: Well Built Robotic BB-8 Droid
text:
Despite unfavorable reviews about the Sphero Star Wars BB-8 Droid, I purchased one as a birthday gift for my wife. Not thinking too much about the quality or what it could do, we were both pleasantly surprised at BB-8. Once charged, and the APP downloaded to my wife's iPhone, we put the BB unit through it's paces. It does take some getting use to, but it is fun and cute. Our large tabby cat hates the droid, he looked at us with that "you must be kidding me" expression but didn't attempt to swat or tackle it.
To learn more about what others think about the droid, we watched a science video about the product. First, except for the two antenna, it is solidly built into an 1/8" thick-walled ball of high impact plastic. To look inside they cut it with a bandsaw as nothing else would work. Once out of the ball, the robot, yes it is a robot, was well built. The maker, Orbotix, manufactures other robotic products, another BB-8 droid is due out soon.
Is it for everyone? Probably not, but my wife likes it and that's what counts. Yes, I would purchase this again.

title: Read reviews before you buy.
text: The manufacturer and seller make more claims than the device is actually capable of. For starters there is no learning (except the operator learning quickly what the Droid can not do). There is no sensor except the bottom for the position of the dome. The app is easy to find on the Google play store but takes alot of room and uses Google play services to download extra data so there is no Amazon version. There is no speaker so any sound it makes comes from the app on your phone. And the sphere makes friction noise. It does travel in the direction that the eye on the dome is facing. This is so not worth the $150. Msrp.

text: All good

title: Thumbs down.
text:
Beware. The product has recently been downgraded so that the magnetism in the head is too weak. As a result EVERY TIME BB8 bumps into a wall (which is often) his head pops off. I had an original BB8 which was great. Then I lost the head when he went under the sofa which has low clearance. Couldn't find it again. So I ordered a replacement head. Ever since that time his head has popped off at the slightest provocation, whenever he hits a wall and even sometimes when he merely roles from a carpet to the hardwood floor, a drop of a tiny fraction of an inch. When I asked Sphero tech support they wrote me back that BB8's head will always pop off if he hits something. That's just a lie. The original head did not pop off like this. Besides if they made a 'blind' robot that bumped into walls a lot and with a head that popped off each time, that would be unacceptable. I sent them a Youtube video I found of a Sphero BB8 demonstrating that what they said about the head always popping off was just completely untrue. So they asked for a video of mine with the head popping off. I sent them a video. I also asked for a new replacement head, hoping the new one would be better. They have not responded.

Overall exhausting and exasperating.

Update. They sent a new replacement head. It's not great but appears to be a little better than the last one. So bottom line, the strength of the magnetism of the head you will receive, and whether or not it pops off constantly, is a coin toss.

title: So worth it :)
text: Bought this as a surprise for my bf. It arrived a lot sooner than the time I thought. Even after I was sent an estimate that was even cut short. So I got it a week or two after purchase. The toy works great and although it's hard to get over the carpet edge... It's super cute! The head attaches with a magnet that revolves around the body so once and a while it might fall off if the droid hits a wall full speed. After a few hours you can master how this works. The speed, options and the hologram projection via the app. For the price it was here it is worth it in my opinion. If you look on eBay they are a lot more. With the Star Wars movie coming out in December and Christmas around the corner this will be a hot item.

title: Very Good
text: Very Good

title: Android users - Install the app BEFORE you buy.  If it won't install, it's a paperweight albeit a nice one.
text:
TLDR; For Android devices owners - Install the app from Google Play before you buy. Otherwise, you may end up with Star Wars collectible paperweight (albeit a very nice one) unless you go to the dark side of custom roms.

Rather than repeat what is already written by the most helpful reviews, I just wanted to focus on a main issue I had with my BB-8. Although my Android phone and tablet appeared to meet the hardware and software requirements listed on the Sphero BB-8 website, the Sphero BB-8 app itself would not install. So, I suggest folks first attempt to install the app on your device BEFORE you purchase BB-8. The app will not install unless it meets ALL of the hardware and software requirements, and just because it looks like your device meets the requirements, you won't know for sure until you attempt to install the app or it's on the list of know supported devices. See the Sphero website for the compatibility list.

MY EXPERIENCE WITH A 2012 GOOGLE NEXUS 7 TABLET
I have a 2012 Google Nexus 7 tablet running a supported version of Android. However, the Sphero BB-8 app will not install because my tablet does not support "Bluetooth LE" (Low Energy). I figured my table has Bluetooth so it will support Bluetooth "LE". I was wrong and spent much time researching what the heck is Bluetooth LE?!?I found that my tablet's hardware could support it, but Google chose not enable it. So the only way to get it to work was to install a "custom rom" which is something that should only be attempted by advanced technical users and is not for the faint of heart (You could brick your device -- render it useless, lose all your data, etc. or worse, lose all your Candy Crush boosters :-P).

MY EXPERIENCE WITH A 2013 SAMSUNG GALAXY S4 MINI DUO PHONE
The app would also not install on my 2013 Samsung Galaxy S4 Mini Duo. AgaIn the device is running a supported version of Android but the app will not install and it's not clear to me why. So , again the only alternative would be spend a lot of time trying to investigate what's missing and whether installing a "custom rom" will fix it (which I haven't attempted because BB-8 is working on my Nexus 7).

LIKES AND DISLIKES
Other than the challenges of getting the app to work, I like but don't love my BB-8. I like the quality and detail and will enjoy it as a nice Star Wars collectible. I wish it had better sensors and was easier to maneuver. I don't see any evidence of "artificial intelligence" or "adapting" and hope either Sphero or some tech fans will create better apps for it. I'm also concerned that the head pops off easily causing the thin antenna to bend and eventually. As many other posters remarked, the marketing video is very misleading.

title: Fun droid. Though thereâ€™s no voice control on Android yet the technology behind BB-8 is genuinely impressive.
text:
If you are a Star Wars fan or just a toy geek this droid is for you. Like Sphero's other toys, the BB-8 connects to iOS or Android devices (Sphero tweeted that it's working on Windows Phone support). Once paired, the companion app offers access to three modes: Driving, Holographic Messaging and Patrol. For the second mode, Sphero used its augmented reality engine to turn videos into Star Wars' trademark holo messages -- those are recorded and viewed on the application. Patrol, meanwhile, shows a real-time log of BB-8's movements, based on the gyroscope and accelerometer sensors from your smartphone or tablet. So even if it's just a toy, it encourages players to learn about programming.
The droid looks great and much easier to drive than I expected. At time of writing the Android app doesn't support voice commands yet even though it says it on the box. But it's meant to be coming soon in an update. Also, it would be a 5 star if the sounds come from the droid not on the phone. However, I really think a â€˜toyâ€™ with this kind of technology goes way beyond a mere toy. What Sphero has done is singlehandedly welcoming in a new generation of toy and consumable robotic technology.

title: Could have been AMAZING ... But isn't.
text:
It's adorable to look at, but when you realize how absolutely incomplete the hardware is, it's a bit depressing.

Droid makes NO SOUNDS. Droid can not hear commands at all. Droid doesn't absolutely nothing without the app running. Yeah, so that pretty much sucks right? Let's elaborate.

It'll beep and boop through your phone's speakers, is totally dependent on the phone to control it (even just for it to explore). I wanted to record a video if it rolling around and beeping, but nope.

It's also tiny. Size of a tennis ball or so. Not a huge deal if not for all of the other issues, but pile it all on and that doesn't help.

Bottom line, it's absolutely adorable, fun to drive around for a bit, but just lacking in so many ways. If it was a $30 toy, it'd be perfect. But at $150? Honestly, up the size a bit, strip the parts off a $50 Android phone and let it look with the camera, beep audibly, listen to voice commands, etc.

If the hardware did all that you'd think it'd do, I'd happily pay double what they're asking, but this is just another toy to sit on my desk at work and do nothing now.

title: BB-8 blew me away!
text:
HOURS AND HOURS OF SUPREME FUN!

This toy comes very close to justifying it's high price tag! It is easy to use (unlike many, many app controlled toys I have had in the past): easy to pair with a control device (you just start the app and hold it near the BB8 unit) and very controllable once you pair. Whether directly controlled or in patrol mode, it does a great job of capturing the character of BB-8 in the movie as well with over a dozen pre-programmed gestures and motions. I have not used the messaging features myself, but my kids (9, 9, & 6 yo) have spent several hours with it as well. While I was concerned about this being a 'single purpose' toy (you know the kind of toy where kids can only play with it one way and then lose interest after an hour or so), my kids keep coming back to it with creative uses, including role / scenario playing, building obstacle courses, and other creative uses (less often than they would like, since they need to borrow my phone to use it - see below).

Battery life typically outlasts my phone (which admittedly has a very average battery, but the phone also doesn't have moving parts the way BB8 does). While I wouldn't bounce it down the stairs, it has been durable so far even with my 6 year old's driving. :)

My only complaint is the limited number of supported control devices. Of the 10 iOS/Android/Kindle phones and tablets we have at our disposal, only TWO are capable of interfacing with it (hence the 4 stars).

(WARNING: as of Dec 2015, NO KINDLE devices were supported.)

title: Great technology, although not so much a "toy" as a working scale model
text:
A few years ago, I bought my brother-in-law perhaps one of the most perfect presents a geek could give another geek--a Sphero remote-controlled ball. It was at the same time completely useless and completely amazing. While remote-control vehicles have been with us forever, it takes a true geek to appreciate the engineering that goes into creating a remote-controlled ball.

I was wondering what Sphero would do for an encore. Whoever the marketing guy was that came up with the idea of approaching the Star Wars: The Force Awakens licensing team should be given a million dollars (although something tells he'll get that and more). It's a product licensing deal made in heaven--cutting edge technology used to make the hottest new droid character, the BB-8, come to life. My only hope for the company is that BB-8 turns out to be more like R2-D2 than Jar Jar Binks as far as how much it ends up being loved by the public.

Like the Sphero ball, the BB-8 works right out of the box. You unbox it and place it on its dock that can be powered by any USB charger. You then download the app from the Apple Store or Google Store. Place your phone or tablet near the unit and it'll recognize it automatically. Once that happens you can start controlling it right away. Unlike the Sphero ball, the BB-8 also has a "head" that's magnetically attached to the ball that remarkably stays on the top of the ball just like the 'real' droid's head.

It takes a bit of getting used to controlling the BB-8. The app will show you two sets of joysticks. You swipe the right one to adjust a flashing blue LED light that animates within the unit, setting it to point directly to you. Once that's done, you control it using standard up-down-left-right joystick controls to the left.

Controlling your BB-8 is lots of fun...just be forewarned that dogs, cats, and the luddites in your life may get just a little freaked out by it and run screaming from it. But everyone else will see it for the cute little robot that it is, It's of course smaller than the real one you see in the movies, but otherwise looks identical. We tried the BB-8 on a hardwood floor where it handled itself perfectly, but when it went onto a tatami mat, it started to get stuck. Best rule of thumb--if you can roll a ball on the surface, you can use the BB-8.

After an initial phase of wonderment and awe just controlling it does get a little old rather quickly (unless you have a remote control car and decide to have drag races). I do like how they included additional features in the app. One is a messaging feature where you record a video message (think Princess Leia recording her message for Obi-Wan in R2-D2) and using augmented reality, when you point your phone's camera to the BB-8, you'll see the video image of your room with the BB-8 displaying a "hologram" (again, a la R2-D2) which transmits the message over and over. Of course, this is of limited practical value as only the image on your screen will show this, not the actual unit, but it still did get oohs and aahs when people saw it.

Another feature of the app is an autonomous mode where the BB-8 will roam your hours on its own, much like a Roomba does. It'll plot out its path on the app as it goes; I would have liked to see it perform some kind of mapping function (how cool would it have been to have the BB-8 measure my room instead of me always having to take the tape measure out), but ultimately its "tour" just resulted in a bunch of random lines. To the BB-8's credit, it's pretty good about not banging into walls. To sum up the apps, they're fun as demonstrations but do fall short of anything of much practical use or value.

The box claims that the robot has "artificial intelligence" and will "learn" and build a personality as time goes on, but this seemed more like marketing fluff to me. Still, hopefully they're working on additional improvements to the app to enable some cool new features.

If I had to sum up, I'd say you'd be best not to think of the BB-8 as a "toy" per se as much as it is a scale model replica of the BB-8 with a glimpse into some very cool technology. Perhaps one day the BB-8 will fetch your slippers or transmit real messages to people in the other room, but for now it's mainly a conversation piece at parties and one of the best movie merchandising products around (appropriate since it was Star Wars and George Lucas who helped movie merchandising take off in the first place).

title: BB-8 is adorable!
text:
This thing is adorable! My first thought when I opened the package was that it was smaller than I expected. The videos really do make it seem a bit bigger than it is.

It came ready to go! The instructions are simple and to the point. Plug it in, put it on the base, log in and download the app. From then it's a bit of a learning curve to get the BB* to go where you want it to go, but it took no time at all to get the hang of it.

I love BB8. I have several collectibles. This was purchased more to go with my collection and for occasional use than for daily play- so I can't give an honest review of how well it holds up after days of play.

I played with this for a couple of hours, much to the delight of my dogs. They loved chasing him around and bouncing back when he got close. They weren't scared at all and got some good exercise in the process.

This is fun for kids, adults, dogs, cats, and anyone/anything else that enjoys chasing robotic toys.

The movement is very smooth. It worked well on my carpet, but worked best on tile and tabletops. As you can probably imagine, he gets caught up on bumps. He does not back up and move around obstacles. He will plow right into them and get stuck. This is typical of any remote control item, and I'm not surprised or displeased by it.

All in all- this is a great toy. I gave 4 stars instead of 5 simply because I felt the advertising was a bit off- I did expect this to be a couple of inches bigger just based on the advertising. It doesn't change how much I love it, but I felt this was enough to drop a star- I would prefer a more honest depiction of his size in the advertisements so that you have a better expectation of what you are getting.

title: Very Cool little Toy but the Cost of Admission is High
text:
I found this at a retail store and picked it up for $150. I'm a Star Wars fan obviously but almost not enough to pay what I did for the toy. It is nicely detailed and fun to play with but $150 is a bit much to ask for what you get. If the toy was a little smarter or had some sounds of its own I think I would have happily paid what I did but it is somewhat limited on its own.

I'm using this with an iPhone 6 and the controls overall work well. Once you get accustomed to where you are pointing it is pretty easy to drive. It can be pretty fast on harder floors and workable although slower on some carpets. The toy does just about nothing on its own. You can attach it to its charger which by the way looks very nice, and if you press the reset button on the charger, the BB-8 head will move around a bit. I think since this toy makes a great display piece, it would have been great if they included some things the droid could do while mounted in the charger. Some noises from the base as well as some specific movements would have been kind of awesome. It would have really given it some function outside of it just rolling around. Unfortunately although the base looks cool, it really just charges your BB-8.

When you're using the app you have a few options. You can do a free control where you drive it around as well as get about 8 commands you can trigger for specific movements like a figure 8 patrol. You have a single joystick for free control which can make things a bit tricky until you get the hang of it. The right side of the controls are used for your commands or setting the direction. When using the right side controls a blue light comes on the droid and shows you the back of the droid and the head turns towards the front so you know which direction you'll be going.

There is a patrol mode that you can start and your droid will stumble around your room crashing into things repeatedly. It's not very smart and although it is cool to see it moving on its own, it is just not smart enough to move around in a logical manner. The final option is message mode which allows you to record a video message with your phone and have the droid project it in augmented reality(looking through your phones camera on the droid) on a nearby wall or just the thin air. It is a pretty cool little feature that despite its limited usefulness is a welcome addition. There is also voice control that seems to be able to be used at any point of controlling the droid. You calibrate your voice and you can tell your droid to follow orders like, "it's a trap," or "look around," where your droid will run away or patrol around respectively.

The droid itself is very nice and shiny. The details are nice and it makes a great display piece combined with the base or even without it. It is made out of plastics but they feel fairly durable for the most part. I don't think they could take many drops of any at more than a foot without cracking but I have not and won't test that on purpose. It also doesn't have any sensors to see the edges of tables so it will drive itself off tables. The head holds on pretty nicely and like it has been described, you'll be cleaning the little rollers in the head like the roller ball in the old computer mouse.

Its actually a great little toy and if this cost closer to $80 or less, I would happily give this 5 stars but it is much more expensive. At $150 I would expect a bit more from the toy. I think not doing more with the base like adding sounds or more features to display the droid nicer was a real missed opportunity. When you pay that money and realize that it does nothing off the base, you're gonna have to justify the cost with playing with it and currently there is limited functionallity

If the price doesn't bother you then take my review as 5 stars because if you're Star Wars fan, you will no doubt enjoy this awesome little droid. If you're not sure you want to spend that much on this toy and you're not a huge Star Wars fan, then owning it probably won't make you feel like you got your money's worth. I can recommend this to Star Wars fans that know what they're getting and don't mind the price. If you're not a huge fan of the franchise and are iffy about spending $150, you should probably wait for discounts or pass this one by.

title: I still love toys like this and I was VERY happy for ...
text: First, let me say that my family got me this for Christmas since I grew up with the original trilogy back in the '70s. All I can say that even now as a grown up with family, I still love toys like this and I was VERY happy for us to play with it. No, I'm NOT disappointed at all, unlike some other reviews. I would've only dreamed of something like this back in the '70s when toys were mostly all about your imagination. Don't get me wrong, there is room for some improvements, but overall it works just fine and gave us lots of fun. We have not had his "head" to pop off hardly at all, unlike some others. It will come off if you drive it full speed and crash into something, but we don't do that often and take care of what we love. I was not expecting a real "holographic" recording, those don't even exist in real life except with maybe Microsoft "Augmented Reality" and such down the road. This is a toy priced around $150 at the time of this review and while it could be about $50 cheaper, I still think it's fine for what it is. All I can say is we ALL love playing with it, both young and grown ups too. So, if you are like me and have fond memories from the '70s and family or young ones to play with, I would highly recommend this toy. May the Force be with you and yours.

title: The product video is fairly misleading here and it can't do a whole lot considering the price
text:
I picked mine up today and was a bit disappointed by what this "droid" can actually do. First a few things it can't do that the product video makes it seem like it can:

-There is no speaker or camera on the droid itself. It can not make any sounds or hear you. The actual app on the phone makes noises but nothing comes from the droid.

-When the droid is on patrol mode it just randomly rolls around and bumps into things. It doesn't actual learn the room or do anything more than pick random directions, bump into objects, and then go in other random directions.

-The head is consonantly falling off as it collides with objects. Would be amazing if you could just roll close to your head and it would pop on but you have to stop what you're doing and manually put it back each time.

+One positive here is the boost mode is pretty fast and fun.

It's a fun little toy but you're not getting a whole lot for this price tag. A little camera on the droid that you could watch on the app and speakers on the droid would have made this a five star product.

title: Small Droid, Huge Price Tag!
text:
So far, this droid has been a PITA (pain in the anatomy). I'm completely frustrated. irritated and am left feeling ripped off.

Size does matter.
The first point to recognize is this is small. No, think smaller. Smaller. The body is about the size of a baseball, maybe slightly smaller. The head is about the size of half a golf ball.
Now, when I first saw the box at Target, I knew it would be small. The box was small. What I did not expect, however, is that the droid itself would be about 1/3 the size of the box! With a retail price of $150-180, it's ridiculously small. Horribly small.

App enabled.
This point worried me. Technology specific items worry me, because I have been burnt with such items in the past. (The "The Batman Interactive Batmobile" comes to mind. It downloaded data from the series. Cool, but, now, useless). But, I heard "This version can do so much more than the Target exclusive". Yeah? Like what? If you can get the app, it seems like it rolls. That's it. Rolls. Oh, i think (but can't prove) it captures short video and audio clips. Anything else? I wouldn't know, there's no manual. $180 and I have to download a manual? REALLY? So, if I do not return this almost $200 baseball sized annoyance, maybe I will download the manual, and see if it does much of anything else.

App, itself.
Thank you for not telling us it requires Android 4.4 (I don't have an Iphone, so unsure what version that requires). I use a stupid phone (which I still think is smarter than most dumb smart phones) and I have a Verizon tablet that I use only when necessary (my kindle is my go-to tablet), that tablet has Android 4.2.2. REALLY? They changed the name between 4.2 and 4.4, and nothing under 4.4 works for this?
Ok, so I try to update. Nope! WHAT? I can't update to 4.4?
Granted, the only way I can cuss out Sphero on this point is, they chose to not write an app for Kindle. They chose to make it for 4.4 and up only. (I'll bet it doesn't work on Marshmallow, 6.0 and up, tho. (Here's where you refer back to my previous point regarding technology specific items). Honestly, i do not know if this is the case, but, would not surprise me. And, if it does still work, I have to wonder at what point it won't. So, for that reason I can and do blame Sphero.

Fun
The 23 hours I have had this, I have not enjoyed it. I regret having purchased it, at this point.

Bottom line:
So far, I am highly annoyed and frustrated by this entire line of technology. I can almost deal with the size (IF i were able to get it to work). IF it worked, I might be more positive on it. So, for those who have the capability of downloading the app, you will find it more enjoyable than me. However, considering the Target version is much bigger, and typically much smaller, and comes with a remote that will work well into the next millenium (assuming one can still get the required batteries) no way I can currently recommend this product. Instead, I think (without having evaluated it) I would recommend the Target version, at this point.

As stated by many others, if things change, so will the review.

text: While this little 4in tall BB-8 is adorable and works very well as a little robot, I'm not convinced it was worth the money. title: great toy, horrible disappointment
text:
The droid itself is adorable.
But I have two huge complaints. Apparently the first time he's activated, he shakes and acts adorable. He will never do this again. So a heads up would have been nice. I wanted my kids to see how cute it was, but made the mistake of trying to be a good mom and charge it on Christmas eve. So they didn't get to see a cute droid reaction like I'd hoped. They could have given a tip about this, but this product literally came with zero instructions. Fancy packaging, but no instructions. :(
The second huge bummer, I got this for an eight year old. Bought him a tablet so he could control it. Turns out, they dont even have a tablet version of the droid app. So we were all dissapointed because he can't even use his two main presents for what they were intended. The app is so huge that he has to borrow his dad's phone when he gets home from work, because not all phones can even run it. And his dad's phone dies quickly running the app. So we all put forth a ton of effort and money, and after the first week, we were all frustrated and now have a $180 toy that the stars have to align for him to play with, so it literally now has dust on it.
It's such a shame. I know plenty of parents did the same thing we did. If you do spend the money on him, make sure you purchase your kid a phone that's compatible too. Really lame that the company didn't put any thought into this.

title: One of the best thought out and executed remote controlled toys produced.
text:
I bought the Sphero BB-8 for my son for his 5th Birthday. The timing of the new Star Wars movie relative to his December birthday could not have been better. I took him to see the movie, and then he received the Sphero BB-8 at the birthday dinner that followed. His reaction was priceless - and alone was worth the purchase. But it gets better.

This toy is incredibly fun to play with - and my 5-year old son immediately was able to control it with ease. The interface is that intuitive. The droid moves and reacts as the movie's BB-8 - because it's essentially just a scaled down version of the original. The preprogrammed behaviors are a lot of fun for my son as well, and the visual effects using your tablet (iPad Mini 2 in our case) or phone are pretty darn cool! This toy is incredibly well thought out, engineered and produced.
To answer the critique that you need a near 'sterile' environment to operate this toy - that is bunk. My son's carpeted bedroom is anything but sterile, and while this toy responds more sluggishly on carpet - it still moves around without any major issues. The only surfaces I would avoid running this on would be concrete, and some types of tile, due to the fact the harder surfaces will degrade the polymer decal on the body of the droid.

The only thing I can think of that I would critique about this toy is that it's a lot of fun for adults too. Thankfully, my son has a relatively early bed time - so I can get some BB-8 time in without frustrating a busy 5-year old.

title: Extremely disappointed Star Wars fan
text:
Very disappointed with this product. I am a HUGE Star Wars fan and I thought it was going to be so cool, but not only was the app not compatible with my Droid Maxx, the actual robot could hardly be considered such, more like a ball with a motor. It just ran into walls, chairs, people, animals,etc... and it didn't even have enough power to make it over the 1/8 inch lip of the carpet from the hardwood floor. Oh and every time it ran into something it lost its head. I ended up returning it for a full refund. The only good thing to come of this purchase was Amazon's incredible customer service, so 5 stars for Amazon.
Unless you want it as a fairly expensive display piece, I wouldn't recommend buying it.

I really with the apps that use a blockly like interface to "program" the droid would work or at least that they would include similar apps for this. There are other apps that you can use to program specific routines from Sphero that will work but it takes a bit more knowledge than the blockly type app so I can do it but my kids struggle with it.

It's also frustrating that the magnet on the head is not as strong as it could be. bb-8's head comes off all the time. On the other hand, maybe it's best that it comes off so easily because this picks up a ton of dust and stores it in the wheels under the head.

When using the "patrol" mode I've noticed bb-8 likes to go over with Molly (our Roomba). I'm sure it's completely harmless but if the robot uprising happens ... I'm sorry.

title: Looks amazing, control is limited.
text:
I think this is an amazing model that looks exactly like what it is: a scaled down version of the amazingly well-made droid BB-8 from the new Star Wars: The Force Awakens movie. However, as an app-controlled robot, it definitely leaves something to be desired.

For starters, There are basically only two modes available: first, a simple driving mode that gives you a touch-screen analog stick to move forward, backward, and turn either left or right, with the speed determined by how far you push the stick from the center. Second, you can put BB-8 into patrol mode, which causes him to bump around your room and find the walls and then humorously move through it once he's found all the walls, but you have no control in this mode. There's also a video recording feature in the app to make a video that looks like the Star Wars holograms, but this doesn't really do anything with the toy.

I am amazed with how much the paint job on both the body and head look just how BB-8 looks in the movie, and it's really fun to watch his head swivel around in patrol mode and do the little leaning look from the first teaser trailer.

The downsides, though, are several. First, the head is somewhat loosely attached to the body via magnets, and while the effect when it's rolling and on top is very cool, it has a tendency to fall off either when picking up BB-8 or when he hits an object at high speed. This is not a huge issue, since you can easily enough reattach the head, but it somewhat ruins the illusion.

Much more troubling though is the lack of interaction with BB-8 offered outside of the driving mode and patrol mode options in the app. Perhaps the app will later be updated to allow more options, but right now that's it and it feels very limited when comparing BB-8 to other robots made by Orbotix, specifically the original Sphero that is the namesake of this robot. Sphero SPRK is my favorite due to it being completely transparent and having a great suite of tools that allow anyone from kids to adults to seniors to find interesting and varied ways to interact with the robot. Between simple object oriented programming to full coding options, Sphero allows far more versatile and creative play options than BB-8. There are also a variety of apps that can interact with the Sphero SPRK, allowing you many more interaction than just a simple driving or patrol mode.

I would recommend buying BB-8 if you love the way it looks and just want to own a piece of the incredible design that went into Star Wars: The Force Awakens. If you actually want a super fun robot with lots of control and programming options, then I would recommend Sphero SPRK instead.

text:
Connecting is an issue with some iOs I have 9.2.1 on an iphone. I've only been able to connect once. Most of the time, it just freezes and a Help Screen Pops up. They are aware as this is was the reply I got back:

Thank you for providing that information. It seems that our app is having trouble integrating with some of the recent iOS updates, and our team is working hard to find a solution to this problem. So please know that we are aware of this issue and doing everything we can to fix it. Once I have more information about a solution, I will follow up with you so we can get your BB-8 rolling again as soon as possible.

We used a mini pad with 9.2.0 and it connected the first try. I haven't tested it again -hopefully, the pairing sticks and I don't have to re-connect everytime we want to play.

When it does work, it's pretty cute. Wish it was a bit bigger. The hologram feature is really cool! I was able to record a Happy Birthday message before giving it the recipient. Hope they fix the software. Apple comes out with software pretty regularly so if they aren't able to keep up, then it becomes useless.

It took a while to get good at controlling it, so fortunately it's sturdy enough to have survived numerous whacks into walls and table legs and accidental trips down the stairs. The only reason I give it a four rather than a five is that I found the setup instructions to be meager. (The customer comments on their support site are really helpful, though, if you're patient to read through them and try a few different things.) Once I figured out how to charge the unit, it's been smooth sailing. Or, more accurately, smooth rolling about. A goofy thing I can do in moments between more important things.

When you run it into a wall, it does respond to the "stimuli" from the accelerometer as a feeling of pain. I think this is interesting that it has feelings. I'm an INFJ so this droid set off my extroverted feeling function even and felt bad for it. Sorry to say but that's a sign of the time that robots are getting feelings, usually reserved for us. title: Cool, but maybe not that cool.
text:
I want to give this a higher score but can't. When I found out the droid in the teaser was real and not cg I just had to have one. And I couldn't wait to buy this mini one. It is very cool and cute. Though not without some issues. Some info in the reviews is delivered in a seemingly convenient way. For instance you can simply use your android or ipad device to control it right? Well only if you have a new model of either. So I get mine home and find out it won't work with my ipad nor with my android phone. I have a friend that says they can update my phone to a firmware or whatever that's compatible. But at the moment I have a $150.oo paperweight, because you can't even put it on patrol without the app. To be clear you can charge the thing without the app, that's all.

I did get to borrow my nephew's iphone to give it a trial run around the kitchen. First the bad. The droid sounds emanate from your device not the droid which diminishes the charm somewhat. Also the antenna on the head are durable but do seem like they can break from heavy use. The reason is that when it moves forward they are mostly fine. But when reversing it can bang them right into whatever may be behind it, a possible oversight in design. The good: it does pretty much everything else you think. It rolls around, banging into walls and changing direction to compensate. It did a little dance or two emoting pride, happiness or frustration I don't know, I didn't get to spend a lot of time with it. It's awesome how it charges inductively without having to plug the droid in, just the base.

It's clear this toy is utterly irresistible. But This is just one voice that says think a little about it before buying. Depending on your income $150.oo might be far too much money for the cute novelty it brings. Maybe wait for the inevitable later models that have improved functionality, and may be bigger.

title: This is so much fun to play with.
text:
I'm a Star Wars fan from the first time I saw the movie in 1977, and while the franchise suffered a setback with Jar-Jar Binks, it has been redeemed with this little droid. Yes, this is more of a novelty item, and there is more that I wish it could do (like really project a holographic message), but the operation of it is really quite easy once you get the hang of it. I'm using the Samsung Galaxy Tab that I got from Costco, and have had no problems with BB8 not working or responding. The only thing I hadn't factored in was that BB8 will show how crappy of a housekeeper I am because it picks up all of the dust from areas I haven't reached, and the head's rollers are like the old computer mice, so those have to be cleaned off when the head doesn't move too quickly.

OK, Sphero. Hurry up and work on the holographic image! I want to be able to have it roll into a co-worker's office to yell at them without having to leave my seat. :-p

title: The product is so subpar in performance that it turns out to be more of a frustration than helping me enjoy the world of Star Wa
text:
I to am returning mine. The product is so subpar in performance that it turns out to be more of a frustration than helping me enjoy the world of Star Wars. Initially, I was able to get my phone connected over bluetooth and it was a bit fun. Next time it took me 2 hours of resetting, restarting, in so many combinations that it was frustrating. It is so inconsistent with its performance that it can only anger you. I was in contact with support and they gave me multiple suggestions that only partly worked. Even the "Watch with Me" was so underwhelming that I cannot justify the money I spent on it and am returning it. Thanks Amazon for your support of the consumer and allowing us to return bad product. I even had my nephew over for the weekend and he was so frustrated by the thing that he thanked me for not getting one for him for his birthday. Don't piss off your family and give this as a gift.

Edit additional info. I worked with their support folks and they finally gave up and said I had a faulty device. The support guy even suggested that he had the same experience as myself but when getting a new unit all was working. Well, I got the new unit today and not only did it not improve, it got worse. This product has not been QA'ed and does not deserve to be on the market. I have spent at least 20 hours trying to get this thing to work both the first and second unit. I so wanted it to work that I gave a number of hours to try. My expert advice, Stay away from this thing like the plague. It doesn't work and I went through 2 of them and many hours. I am extremely disappointed.

According to the description there more things he can do but I suspect that they require reading instructions and that's not something most people do these days. He said that they figured out how to make the head stop moving when it charges because it's 'creepy', a word that his mother and sister also used to describe it. His father told me that it only works with new technology - older operating systems won't interface at all. Overall I think it has much more capability that many children will use so I'm guessing that it will be a flashy toy that finds its way to a shelf sooner rather than later.

title: VERY misleading
text: This is just an over priced sphero that doesn't do half as much as the normal sphero can. I was disappointed to find out that it doesn't send messages at all the only one that can see the supposed holographic message is the person who is controlling it and actually wrote the message which is only visible through the phone. The toy it self doesn't make any sounds and there is no type of learning AI as stated on the box . It also has to be on solid surfaces I have short carpet flattened from wear in my house just slightly taller than you would find in a office the thing is constantly getting stuck unable to move . I thought maybe it was defective as I could easily roll a ball of the same size without resistance across so I exchanged it at the store I bought it at only to have the same problem with the new one. Upon further problems I tried the almighty Google to find out any one else was having this problem then it became easy to see that upon any search of bb8 sphero problems the results were flooded by advertisements and sponsored reviews making it hard for anyone to find out how misleading and false they are advertising this . The best reviews you will find are right here on amazon where you will find people having similar complaints and problems with it. Definitely not worth the money.

title: This is the droid you are looking for!
text:
First be warned, you need the most recent iOS on either tablet or iPhone for the app to work. For a user to be able to control this you have to have a newer iPhone or Android phone or tablet. You should be fairly current on your iOS/OS. You also need bluetooth on your device.

The box is super heavy duty and handsome. Get the droid out and charge it up. While doing that go to the App Store or Google Play and get the app (its free.) Once the droid is charged, turn on your Bluetooh.

Turn the volume down on your device because the app launches, very loudly, with Star Wars theme music. The app will connect to BB-8.

Once you are connected, you will be taken through a tutorial (don't skip this!) You have several options: patrol, driving mode, or watch the Force Awakens together. You can also have BB-8 make sounds, nod yes, etc.

I am not that great at steering it but I am old. I am sure a 12 year-old will master this in about 5 minutes.

The most fun thing is watching the movie together, Put him in his doc, and plug in your device, put the movie on and watch what BB-8 does. Its pretty awesome.

title: Great toy I'm not getting paid to write this
text: One thing I will say with the BB-8 its not your normal driod.  First off they only give you the charging cable and not the plug in adapter so prepare for that surprise.  The antennas on the head are very easy to break but not necessary for connection. Also when you install your BB-8, you will receive an email that will send you a you tube link.  WATCH THE VIDEO BEFORE PLAYING WITH YOUR BB-8.  I was upset because I thought mine didn't work just to realize in the long run it was my fault for not properly using the device.  Mind you, I had it over a month now.  Slow the speed down when running on smooth surfaces and watch him when he's on a table.  The patrol mode is very cool.  At times when I accidentally get him stuck under my couch, the patrol mode can drive him on out on its own.  The unit is very innovative but you gotta pay attention.  Don't expect it to be like your regular RC toys that do what they are told.  If the sensor comes off line you can guide the blue light to you and keep going again.

title: so we decided to test the toy out just in case so that we could return it rather than send it on to the nephew and it be a waste
text:
My mother in law told my husband and I that our nephew was dying to have this toy. For most of her visit, the price of this tiny toy was the brunt of our jokes. $150 for a toy that is basically a remote control car?

Well, my brother in law told us to order it for the kid's birthday and paid for it, so we did. My in laws live in a different country, so we decided to test the toy out just in case so that we could return it rather than send it on to the nephew and it be a waste of money, or much worse, have a disappointed 9 year old on our hands.

As it turns out, we had to eat our words because this is a pretty cool toy. It reacts to the way you drive it around, so if you cause it to run into things it will really lay into you. It's really cute and I know later this month my nephew will be very excited to open this gift. As adults my husband and I had a good bit of fun for a few minutes while testing it, so we know he will enjoy it.

title: Really cool toy for star wars fans,  not for small kids though.
text: This looks and moves just like the real BB-8.  Gave it to my nephew and he loves it.  The built in app has other features like a messaging feature and the BB-8 almost has a mind of its own in the way it moves.  All i can say is the kids love it.  The size is pretty small, looks bigger in the pictures  maybe like the size of  croquet ball lol,  i guess not that many people know the size of of the croquet ball but  it's about 7cm wide but seems wider then that.  What's cool is you set it in it's base and it charges via a usb cable, and it says it will go about an hour on a charge.  The bad thing is if you have very small kids,  the head is on there magnetically so kids can pull it off  and chew off the antenna and swallow it accidentally, so it's not for small kids.  It's controlled by your ipad/iphone or android device.  The app is cool,  you can put a message (record a video) and it shows a scene like it's playing your message like how R2D2 played back holographic messages, except it's just simulating it on the phone or tablet.  You control bb-8 through the phone/ipad as well but it can be controlled by voice as well.  The movement looks just like BB-8 so it's pretty cool watching the head moving around and stuff.

title: Be sure to check if your device is really compatible
text:
Sphero jumped the gun on releasing this product as Android compatible; not all Android devices are built alike. I have a Samsung Galaxy Tab with the 4.4.2 OS and another LG device with 4.4, compatible operating systems according to Sphero. Got BB-8 out to charge and proceeded to download the app from Google Play and received a message that my device is not compatible. Sent Sphero support a few tech support messages with only a canned response that they will get back to me. Today I went to the Sphero tech support site and now see that they have added another requirement for use -- a device equipped with a gyroscope, amongst a few others. Apparently neither of my devices have this. Sadly, I just packed BB-8 back up to Return to Sender.

From Sphero's website:

Android devices, while having OS 4.4.2 or higher, must have all of the following hardware in order to operate with BB-8. Without this hardware, the Sphero BB-8 app will not show up for download in the Google Play store.

Bluetooth
Bluetooth LE
Front Camera
Rear facing camera if want to use the Holographic messaging feature
Microphone
Distinct Multi-touch Landscape Touchscreen
Hardware sensors including gyroscope and accelerometer
WiFi capabilities

title: Four Stars

title: Things to know before you buy
text:
This is a fun toy! It hooks up easily to a smart phone, makes noises like from the movie and keeps kids entertained. With that said some things the description is vague about I want to clear up.

Controls: has a virtual joystick on your smart phone/tablet. It takes about 10 minutes to get used to learning it's movement habits. Have a pretty open floor otherwise getting it unstuck can be frustrating.

Hologram - this is not a real hologram, it's an augmented reality trick. This means it turns on your phones camera, you look at the BB-8 through the camera and it creates a hologram look in your phone. See picture for example.

Patrol Mode: it moves around on its own making noises, keep app open otherwise it cuts connection and make sure there is room for it to roam.

Sounds: the droid itself does not make the sounds, they come through the phone, a little hokey but I don't feel it takes away from the effect.

Those are the main points, enjoy and have fun...may the force be with you.

title: Love this little guy
text: Love this little guy. There is a button on the side of the base that can be used to erase the bluetooth connection to reconnect. He doesn't do very well on carpet and on tile he is very slippery. So there is that, but it is still nice to have my very own BB-8

title: Don't BB-8'in!!
text:
I love this toy. I hate even calling him a toy. I guess I didn't have as high of expectations as some people do regarding his capabilities because I'm thrilled. But I work in tech, so for $150 I feel he was a bargain.

As soon as I saw the video Sphero made I knew I had to have one. I squealed so hard when I put him on his charger the first time and he came to life. I've only had him for a few days, but I love just putting him on patrol when I'm lounging around the house. I find myself talking to him, even scolding him when he decapitates himself on some of my lower furniture. I'm not sure about the 'adaptive' capabilities he has, but if I hold him and make a beeping noise similar to one of his, he'll make the same one back (out of his canned responses)

Some people are upset he doesn't work with their device, but it's not like that information is a big secret. Do some research before dropping $150. Yes, his vocals come from your phone and not the droid itself, but to me that's a minor disappointment. This droid is heavy-duty. I have slate floors, I've dropped him from about 4 feet and aside from his head flying off he's good as new. He can roll over cords and rugs, but really hits his stride on hard surfaces.

His personality is adorable, and even if he just sat on his charger, shivered and beeped at me I woulda bought him.

title: Awesome, at first.
text:
I gave this to my 12 y/o daughter for her birthday, and for about two weeks she was in love! Then it wore off and she doesn't play with it anymore. I asked her about it last week and she said that it's capability seems pretty limited and I think she's right. You can drive it around, but you need to stay in sight of it because it can't take video to show through the controller. It can move around autonomously, but it can't learn it's environment.

I rated this 4 stars because it is a cool product and does exactly as promised, however I think we are in an age where for this price it should do more.

title: This is NOT the Droid you are looking for....
text: I don't have one and based on the several dozen reviews I read, I am  not going to get one. I am a LONG TIME Star Wars fan...38 years a fan to be exact, and in this day and age, even from a toy, I expect way more than this, Engineers. The developers need to realize that people my age grew up with Star Wars and watching The Jetsons in their flying cars....we still don't have, Star Trek, Battlestar Galactica, and the like... It's a cute Droid, but it seems to me that more time was put into outward appearance and functionality with regard to movement (which sounds a bit like a Roomba, with less brains....sorry peeps!) than fine tuning the actions and abilities the Droid can offer for the upper-end of moderate pricing. Also, I would expect my dog to freak out at the presence of a Droid rolling around the house, as it is, she is not friends with an unplugged vacuum, as she is aware of its noise capabilities. If I am going to invest in a toy, droid or race car...it can't be described as "fragile" and "easily broken", etc... It has to stand up to bumps and bashes and the occasional sniff or paw of a dog... Do better and you may just get my dollars. This is not the Droid you are looking for.

title: Great Product - a few minor things to prepare for beforehand
text:
The BB8 is pretty much what you expect. Great detail, sturdy material, superior packaging. Its a lot of fun, as much fun as a remote controlled car. it's also really fun just to watch, it is so well made that you think that this is the actual design from the movie.
What you don't expect is that the app running and connected by Bluetooth is the only way the BB8 stays awake. If you have to use your tablet or smartphone device for anything else the toy goes to sleep. Now the sounds and movements are also generated by the app, so it pretty much rolls around without any noise except for the gyros and motors causing it to move. It would have been even better if there was an actual working sensor in the unit, maybe a camera or even a infrared proximity sensor but nothing even though the app generates info its all just based on collision feedback ... so expect the little guy to run into everything. The controls are a bit of a challenge at first, you have to line up the unit with your mobile device, so that when you push forward the unit goes forward. Unlike an rc car you always know where forward is ... this unit because of its shape and unique movements you really can't tell when it is turned around and controlling it becomes guesswork. Finally the induction charging station is not as fast as regular device chargers, you get an hour of full action but it has to stay on the base for 3 or more hours to fully recharge ... although the unit does manage its power use well, you get an hour run time in total, there is no leaking of power as the unit goes to sleep once not in use.

title: Five Stars
text: Love this BB8..hope to be able to use the force-band with it!

It takes some getting used to controlling the droid as he occasionally has a mind of his own, yet the droid is a fantastic buy. Even if you aren't the gadget fanatic like most of us are, it is still a nice piece of memorabilia to add to the collection. As for me, a 28-yr old, I purchased about a week ago, and have had a blast with it. Fortunately for iOS users, there's an app that allows for in-depth creativity in controlling BB-8 called Tickle App. It allows you to somewhat choreograph his functionality. For instance you can make him light up different colors and program him to do different things. The more creative you are, the more fun you can have.

Apparently Sphero has future plans to release more capability features for BB-8, also.

title: The droid you've been looking for
text: This has turned out to be a very good purchase indeed for my fiancÃ© and I (mid 20s), our 2 cats, and one dog. Initially we enjoyed playing with BB8 driving him around and enjoying the various settings available. We really liked watching Force Awakens with him and it added a dimension to the movie not present otherwise. But what has really turned out to be the best part is how much our dog (mostly) and cats enjoy playing with him on patrol mode. We're currently very busy and don't have as much time to play with the dog, who is a retriever mix and needs stimulation. Ever since we started letting BB8 patrol, our dog has become significantly happier and we are able to keep him entertained without being too involved. BB8 rarely gets stuck and will roll around for hours. I'm very grateful for this fact alone. Ignore he ever dies I, buying him again.

title: Avoid. Huge disappointed
