First it's Very small. Much smaller than you think (size of a tennis ball)
But more important - it doesn't do much!
It is a remote controlled battery powered small ball that rolls. That's basically it.
The voice command almost never works
The hologram message is actually done by your smartphone video recording.
The head of this thing may make you think it has some sort of a camera but it's just a plastic mock up.

And the "self learning of the environment" feature? I am still wondering what is it. Have not seen a sign of that.

Kids have played with it for 1-2 days and then left it because there is not much you can do beyond just controlling this slow speed very limited robot (it can't move on carpets and slips a lot on a wood floor)

title: Well made toy, evil and clueless company.
text:
As a kid who grew up with the original Star Wars toys of the 70's and 80's, I really wanted to like this BB-8. Unfortunately, due to it's lack of usable features and an app that hands ultimate control of YOUR droid over to an incompetent bunch of hacks, mine is going back.

When my BB-8 arrived at my door, I was excited. I had watched all of the videos online, and I was really expecting to enjoy having my very own BB-8, made by the same company that built the unit used in the movie. The packaging was top notch, and opening the box felt like I was about to see something well worth the $150 price tag. The unit itself is well made, with a very sturdy and sound fit and finish. The materials are obviously high end, and no one is going to confuse this as a child's toy. This is a quality replica, and the design is absolutely collector grade.

Sadly, the function doesn't live up the look and feel. After downloading the app and synching up with the droid, you quickly realize that there are only about 10 or so things that you can actually do with the droid, and that makes for about 15-30 minutes of play time before it's just plain boring. I guess if I had a pet to chase around the house with it, it may have gotten a little more mileage...but honestly, how long can rolling a ball around the floor really hold your attention? There are cool internal lights, but no way to activate them on command. There are eight pre-programmed actions, but you can only see four of them at a time. And even after you start to get the hang of switching back and forth between the pre-programmed action menus, you have to back out to the direction menu to re-orient the directional controls every five minutes when the droid's sense of true north gets out of whack. It's really just far more fun to look at than it is to actually play with, and that's just disappointing.

Even with all of the functional shortcomings, I was still planning to keep the droid as the ultimate desktop conversation piece...until today. Today the Sphero folks made it very clear that this toy is not ready for prime time when they sent out two "transmissions" from C-3PO and R2-D2 to highlight the "messaging" feature of the BB-8. You would think that would add interesting and fun content to the BB-8 "Star Wars" experience, but instead they just spammed my app with two upside down thumbnails that make it look about as professional and believable as Jar Jar Binks. Not only did they ruin the appearance of my messaging menu, they sent an additional software/firmware update along with the message that doubled the initialization time of the app. So now it's slower and lamer, with absolutely no added benefit.

Obviously concerned, I wrote the company and asked what could be done to correct these issues. Their response was that there is nothing that could be done to correct the orientation of the images, and that there was no way to undo any update that had been pushed through. Further, there was no way to disable automatic updates, no way to opt out of these second rate spam messages, and basically no way to take control of the device that I had paid for. They would maintain control in perpetuity, whether I wanted them to or not. That means they can strip the app of any function that I may enjoy, force changes to the interface whenever they're feeling "creative", and basically alter MY droid at will in any way they see fit until it dies. Now I could understand if this were some sort of networked unit that needed to stay current to interact with all of the other devices on the network, but this is a stand alone toy. There is absolutely no reason a person shouldn't be allowed to purchase this droid and keep it in its original out-of-the-box configuration, if they so desire. In fact that's kind of a big deal to Star Wars collectors. But they couldn't care less. After all, they already got your money.

I guess Steve Jobs would be proud of Sphero's ability to sell a toy and maintain complete control over it forever, but any free thinking individual who grew up on Star Wars toys of the past should be appalled. I for one will never pay $150+ for a toy that can only be played with at the pleasure of the manufacturer, so I'll be taking my control(and money) back.

title: Buyer Beware
text:
I am a huge Star Wars fan, and put this on a wish list for the family. My Mother in Law bought it and I excitedly opened it on Christmas. I wanted this thing to do what it says it will do, I would have been willing for it to be expensive remote control memorabilia at a minimum.

I took it out of the box, and loaded the app. I took it off after charging about 30 minutes to give it a chance. It immediately started spinning out of control. Then I loaded it back on the charger and reset it. Then I took it off and the remote feature worked like it was supposed to for about a minute before it just stopped. I thought it may need a charge, so I put it on the charger for overnight charging. The next day I took it off the charger and it worked for 10 seconds. Then I charged for another 3 hours (according to the manual, it will be fully charged after the light stops blinking and remains solid. This would always happen in about 2 minutes.) I took it off and it worked for 10 seconds, repeated this cycle the rest of the day. Then I started digging for on-line reviews and this was a common problem. I returned it.

Star Wars fan or not, I am insulted that a $150 toy works as poorly as this one. Some people will buy anything Star Wars and never open the box. My range of emotion on this was high from excitement to feeling ripped off (That someone else would pay that much for a dud for me). I could have had a dud, but I did not feel that way when I researched problems and read about the same problems over and over. The basic premise is awesome, but it doesn't mean anything if the product can't deliver basic consistent functionality.

if you are looking for a RC that can do tricks or fancy things, or that you can program like the regular sphero, you should look elsewhere, but if you are looking for something fun, that looks great, reminds you of the new star wars movie and will make you smile, buy this!

title: Could use a lot of improvements.
text:
I have very mixed feelings about this... It seems like it's still in the prototype stage; there could be a lot of simple improvements.

I love BB8. He's one of my favourite characters in all the Star Wars movies, so naturally having a mini-BB8 rolling around the office makes me very happy. It's super cute, and I was pretty impressed with how Sphero managed to get his head to move the way it does in the movie, considering we're not quite yet at that level of technology.

BUT

His antenna snapped off pretty much immediately, and he didn't run into anything with that much force.

And my biggest disappointment: the sounds ONLY come out of your phone. No sounds from the actual BB8. I'm kind of baffled as to why. Sphero managed to get his movements down pretty well, but they couldn't install a small speaker system?

All in all, we still love him (and so do the cats), but I definitely do not think it's worth the normal retail price. If we had not purchased it on sale, we'd probably be returning it.

title: This is the Droid you're looking for.
text:
This is the coolest toy I've ever had, and I'm 33. The folks at Sphero clearly were in a rush to get the product out the door for the movie release, but they've kept their promise to update him, and I expect that they will continue to unlock the immense potential of this little guy in the coming months.

Pros:
-Sooooo cute! The little autonomous head movements make him feel alive. He's just full of personality.
-Good battery life. I've yet to have him run down on me during a play session (though I don't think I've tried to push the hour mark)
-Durable. The body is made of very thick plastic. He's taken some tumbles, and though the head will sometimes fall off in an impact, he doesn't have a scratch on him. He takes a lickin' and keeps on tickin'.
-Controls are easy to learn and use.
-Sphero continues to update the actions and sounds available.
-Compatible with other programs like SPRK Lab and Tickle (iPhone only) for infinite programming and customization. This allows you to use BB-8 like a regular Sphero. He's more versatile this way, but not as cute. It's the head movements that really make him special, and older Sphero programs don't account for that added motion.
- Voice commands are pretty fun, though there are only a few to choose from.

Cons:
- The current interface is very limited. There are 12 programmed actions, and you can of course drive BB-8 freely. There's no light functions to play with, and Sphero cannot put the program on an open platform because of the Star Wars licensing agreement.
- BB-8 runs a bit more sluggish in his specific control program than he does in custom programs like SPRK Lab.
- Patrol mode is worthless. BB-8 does not "remember" when he bumps into something, so he just keeps running into the walls and getting stuck in remote corners. Annoying. It would be so much better if he could somehow use distance from your phone or GPS to actually navigate spaces, like a Roomba does. This just may not be possible, but I hope to see better functionality in updates.
- Hologram mode does not work that well on my Samsung S5; the image often doesn't line up correctly with the robot, so the image just randomly projects in space. The record function is pretty cool, though. It's just kind of glitchy right now. Hopefully Sphero will update this function.
- No "follow me" or "come here" function. This seems like it would be pretty simple to implement. Another function I hope to see in an update.
-It would have been SUPER COOL to have a little camera in the head. I know, power issues, it would be too heavy, etc. But I can dream, can't I?

Overall, this is a really excellent little piece of technology, but its capabilities are not even close to being fully utilized at the moment. With some added voice and command functionality, and improvement of the patrol mode, I might just never put him down. Well done, Sphero. I look forward to your next updates for my little droid buddy.

title: Sphero made a major snafu in lack of app/phone support, but this is a neat toy
text:
Well, as others have written in their reviews, the challenge with the BB-8 is finding a phone that is compatible with the app. I think Sphero really messed this one up by not putting the effort into development of the apps to allow older phones to control BB-8. It's easier to determine which apple devices are compatible with the app, but good luck with android devices.

Your child will need access to an iphone 4s or later and hopefully the app will behave. My issue is that it's not unusual for younger children to get older iphone hand-me-downs and thus, the iphone 4 won't work in our case. If you upgrade to the latest iphone every 2 years, then you probably have a 4s, 5, 5s available. But otherwise, you'll need to shell out another $225 to $600 for your little one to have a phone with a gyroscope, accelerometer, and other specs needed. We're looking at an ipad mini as the best path forward. To be sure, I'll plan to go into the Apple store to be certain that it will be compatible with the sphero app.

Sphero, you need to consider the demographics of users you have before tossing something out onto the market. Even if you decide to go forward as you have, please be clear and up front about the requirements for the app to control this thing rather than surprising people.

I give it three stars though, since the BB-8 itself seems to work fine with my iphone 5s (which I have to frequently give up to my child to use). Yes, the head falls off quite a bit and I agree with many other criticisms I've read. But this is a cool toy that will be in episode 7 when it comes out. Hopefully, BB-8 in the movie maneuvers with a little more grace to survive the attacks I've seen in the trailers, but then again, has a storm trooper ever hit anything?

UPDATE:
We got an IPod touch, and it works perfectly! Gets a little boring after a while, however it is really fun!

Fairness must rule the day: I contacted Sphere about the issue and I am awaiting their reply if they are going to send me another cable. I will append this review based on their reply.

Now, the toy is a pleasure to use and learn. The app you download is easy to understand and use and works on either IOS or Android type phones. You should go to their website to make sure your phone will work with the unit before you buy. All in all....a pleasure to have and play with.

title: and it's been a pretty awesome toy in that time
text:
I bought this while standing in line at toys-r-us on Force Friday, after the store announced they wouldn't be getting any of these little guys in. It just dawned on me that I've now had this little droid for two months, and it's been a pretty awesome toy in that time. I'll pull it out sporatically to have him roam around the house, and the dogs don't even mess with him anymore. My nieces really enjoy playing with him when they're over. My boyfriend and I have left countless cheesey hologram recordings on it to reach other, not to mention the obligatory "you're my only hope!"... All around a really sturdy, neat item.
A few pointers, though:
*Unless you have a giant phone, download the app on a tablet, if available, it's truly a much more enjoyable experience
*BB8s head WILL pop off of you run him smack dab into a wall, or other hard surface.
*just like playing rainbow road for the first time, take it slow! His turbocharged controls are a little hard to work with the first few go's.
*the voice commands are a neat feature that I can never, ever seem to get right. "Its a trap!" usually turns into "go to sleep" soooo I guess I mumble?
*I've taken him outside once or twice, and he actually did OK on the uneven concrete, with narry a chip or paint defect to report.

I've fiddled with the harbro BB8 and was not very impressed. While it's much larger than the sphero BB8, it seems much more cheaply made. Its something I'd maybe think about to get my nieces, but with the app control function, I'm really happy with the sphero product.

They made a pretty good commercial, the advertising was super cool, but the actual product is meh... not worth the price.

title: Perfect for Howard Hughes. Useless for the rest of us.
text:
If you happen to live in a clean room environment that Howard Hughes would envy, this is the toy for you. For the rest of us who live in houses that aren't vigorously scrubbed every time we want to use your BB-8, this toy is fairly useless. After just a few minutes of operation it wobbles around because it's picked up so much lint. The smooth ball attracts lint and dog hair like a magnet. It didn't take long for the little wheels in the head to look like the wheels in a non-optical mouse do after a year of operation. What makes it worse is there doesn't appear to be any way to clean them. The little wheels have slits in them that get dog hairs get wrapped around. I can't see there's any way for the manufacturers to fix in future versions other than making it possible to take apart the head to clean it.

Two other points that make this toy not the best buy:

1. When the battery dies, so does your BB-8. There's no way to replace it because the ball is glued together during the manufacturing process.
2. If the app stops working, the BB-8 is rendered worthless. So if the manufacturer decides they don't want to update the app for future versions of IOS, you'll end up with a $150 paper weight.

title: Nice collectible but not sure it's worth the cost
text:
This is a nice piece for those wanting to make it a collectible.

Packaging: Very nicely done. Quality cardboard and the graphics on the box are well detailed.

BB-8: feels very well made and very good detail on its body and head.

Use: the app is pretty straight forward and the unit itself goes well on hard surfaces, although struggles quite a bit in carpeting. I used an iPhone 6 and did not have any connectivity issues. BB-8 is not easy to drive tho, I found the controls to maneuver BB-8 a bit difficult at times and when I allowed my niece and nephew to play it they had difficulties in navigating it as well.

Overall is a nice toy/collectible however it's not worth the cost especially since it does not navigate easily.

Note to developers: add battery life display in app to determine how much battery life is left.

title: Update for 2 stars.
text:
Iâ€™m updating this after two years. The BB-8 droid is fantastic...for a year or so. Then itâ€™s garbage. Iâ€™ve taken mint condition care of mine, having only used it moderately. For $150 I expect to have a long life out of a device. But, what was awesome is now useless crap. Iâ€™ve tried the updates, the resets, and wasted a great deal of time researching how to revive my droid. Time, frankly, Sphero should reimburse me for. Itâ€™s a shame such a promising company ultimately fails and disappoints in the end. Fine for large educational institutions that can simply drop More budget on replacements. Crappy when itâ€™s actually a hard working teacherâ€™s money buying the device. Sphero wonâ€™t be getting my money in the future.

This little droid is truly a new wave of gadget, and the quality and fun of it make it an awesome product. I certainly understand others' frustration with the connectivity issues they seem to be having. However, for me it synched right up and was a blast - up and running after a quick charge. It is actually quite simple to operate and designed with very clear instructional icons and operating features. I expected it to be far more complicated than it was and once I slowed down for two seconds to read what the tutorial was saying it all fell into place. As another reviewer said, if you watch the commercial it is very clear what this toy can and can't do. (Of course it doesn't project holograms from the unit itself; that technology doesn't EXIST yet.) The app is extremely well thought out and smartly designed as a solid partner to the droid, not as a gimmicky after thought. Its ability to respond instantly and mimic BB-8's movements in the movie is excellent and makes it a huge design achievement.

title: Your cat will love you forever and give you cuddles and you will annoy your facebook friends with Cat+BB-8 photos
text:
This gets 5/5 ot 9/10.

First, the bad. Unfortunately, the unit suffers from some mild "false advertising" from what I can see, the toy does not "learn" from your interactions, in any way that I can reasonably tell. Plus, the advertising would lead you to think it has some time of obstacle detection when really it's just an accelerometer (a hard bump will cause it to flash red and it will emote). Finally, I'm not sure it's a criticism or a requirement of the design (probably the latter, friction = coeff*normal force) but the head's magnet is only strong enough for moderate bumps, so about 1/20 times the head can pop off during operation, but still operates fine. The biggest of all of my complaints: the toy has no speakers of it's own, so any noises it makes are completely driven by the app on your mobile device.

Now the good. Have you seen how freaking cute this cat is? LOOK HOW HAPPY THIS DROID-LOVING CAT IS.

Yes, I'm an undergrad mechanical engineer, and I wanted the toy for science and all that, but I really truly brought this Primarily because I knew it would be THE ULTIMATE CAT TOY. Rick (the cat) absolutely loves it, he stalks it, he sniffs it, he pounces it - and when he pounces it I count a kill if the head comes off. If you have a cat who loves chasing things YOU MUST BUY THIS TOY.

The toy is very good on a range of surfaces, but does best on thin carpet. The rollers on the head will collect lint but thats very easy to clean off. The toy is a lot of fun just to hold and mess with, the gyroscope tries to keep the unit "upright" while it is powered, so you can have fun tossing it up in the air, putting spin on it, etc. - spin it on the kitchen floor like a top, it just keeps going.

The app is pretty good, I have not explored all the features, I just use Drive mode and patrol mode. Patrol mode is somewhat OK for enticing the cat but I have found the best tactic for fluffy antagonistic mischief is manual drive - get the droid out of the cats field of vision and he feels inclined to chase after it. At the end of the day, this toy has caused me to create an emotional bond with it, and it is so fantastic that I liken it to the invention of the Ball or Sliced Bread or the advent of Transformer toys. This is one of those once in a generation kind of gadgets, frankly, that will get you excited (or your kids or your cat). If the toy had its own speaker, it would probably be even that much better at amusing the cat!

title: Not Worth a penny
text:
if you are disappointed now, wait and see what they will respond when you ask for help because the battery is not charging any longer:

Thank you for your patience. I am sorry to hear that your BB-8 Battery is no longer holding.

Over time, lithium batteries degrade, and it does appear that your battery has reached the end of its life. You can confirm this by charging your robot for three hours, and then removing it from the charging base. If the robot does not turn on, or it flashes long red lights, this indicates your battery is critical. Because the shells are fused together, there is no way to replace or repair the battery.

We wish our batteries would last forever - there are two main reasons they are unable to.
1. Age - over time all rechargeable batteries lose capacity, and eventually die
2. Charging Cycles - in healthy batteries, ions flow between a cathode and an anode. When you charge a battery, ions move from the cathode to the anode. When you're using the battery (playing with your robot), ions move from the anode to the cathode. Over time, this process wears out the cathode, reducing the battery's capacity.
Even when batteries are not being used, their lifetime performance degrades. Batteries that are not used can lose 20%-35% each year depending on storage climate and temperature.

Since you are outside of our one-year warranty, unfortunately, we are unable to replace the robot.

I apologize that I am unable to offer a better solution.

Thank you,

Christophe
Sphero Customer Advocate
Email | support@sphero.com
Support Hours | Monday - Thursday 8am-5pm Mountain Time

I have to admit, great Marketing, but a TERRIBLE product.

Not buying any more Sphero products will let everybody know that it is not worth itâ€¦.this is a disposable product, use for a year, and through it out or cut in half and replace the battery ourselves.

title: I had fun playing with this droid
text:
Sphero has been known for their ball shaped app controlled robots. Now it has been taken a step further. Sphero took that same robot ball with a new twist. Adding a new part to it. And made BB-8.
BB-8 is from the Star Wars Ep. 7 : Force awakens. Hes shown through out the movie. I first saw this droid. on display in various stores in shopping malls here in hawaii. This is what first got me into sphero's star wars series. I had fun playing with this droid. The sounds come from the phone app. The colors are screen accurate. The charging for BB8 is done on a base by induction charging,. The head rests on the body by a magnet. It still looks good.
How durable is this droid? The machine is encased in a thick polycarbonate shell. Sealed all around. It can go in water. For me the real test is how well it can stand up to my dog. I had my dog chase BB8 while i controlled it . It stood up to the jaws . the bitting. Pretty much my dog tossing it around. Its his favorite play thing.

It works great with my iphone.  it will get stuck when going between surfaces of different thicknesses like from a smooth floor to a thick rug, but it runs just fine on the carpet in my house which is fairly standard.  As other reviews mentioned, ithe sound effects come fromtye app on your phone, not from the bb8 figure itself.

title: A fun and exciting device, with limitations
text:
This is a fun device. There are weaknesses, but overall it is enjoyable. It responds quickly and is fairly easy to control (the limitation being the touch screen, rather than a physical controller, and works across a variety of surfaces. I lose control on a titled floor, and it is slow to start and on a thicker carpet. It does take a little while to learn to drive, but it has very realistic movements with experience.

My major complaint is the antennae on its head. The material is too stiff, and the longer antenna broke off almost immediately, the first time it ran into something. A softer rubber would have prevented this.

title: I love BB-8 so I am totally satisfied with this product
text:
So I couldn't get BB-8 to sync with my Surface running Windows 10. Turned out to be a privacy setting issue. Make sure Bluetooth is on and you paired with him in your Bluetooth settings. Then go to
-->Settings
-->Privacy
-->Other Devices
-->Sync With Devices (should be turned ON)
Let your apps automatically share and sync info with wireless devices that don't explicitly pair with your PC, tablet, or phone.

This was an instant fix.ï»¿ I love BB-8 so I am totally satisfied with this product. It would be nice if he came with some more instructions/troubleshooting tips. Ultimately fun to play with. It's like having your own tiny BB-8. What fun!

title: A cute app controlled droid with limited functions and a hefty price tag
text:
The Sphero BB-8 is cute and fun to play with for about 10 to 15 minutes, then becomes a very cute shelf sitter. My husband (a huge Star Wars fan) asked for this for Christmas and ultimately ended up returning him less than a week later.

1. We knew going into this that the sounds do not come from BB-8 himself but from your smartphone, but it's annoying to have to carry your phone around with you everywhere when he's just "exploring," especially since you have to keep the app running and draining your battery.

2. The voice commands really don't do much. My kids kept yelling out the prompts that came with him (only about 10) but yet it still didn't stop BB-8 from rolling down the stairs. Twice.

3. He loses his head. A lot. There's nothing like turning around to find a headless BB-8 roaming the house and then having to hunt for his head. We once found it in the bathroom, then under the dining room table, then in a corner.

4. Like other users have said, if you have an older molder Android phone, don't expect to be able to use the app. My poor husband was so disappointed when he installed the app only to see a message that said his OS was too old to support it. He had to use my iPhone, which defeats the purpose of him having the droid.

5. He's small. Like, really tiny. It didn't bother us too much, except that he kept rolling under the couch and would get stuck there, or lose his head trying to get out. Make sure you don't have anything in the way that could trap him.

All in all, if you have $150 to blow and don't care about limited functions and average performance, he's really cute and fun to break out during parties. Otherwise save yourself the money and wait for the next more improved model, which I'm sure is coming sometime soon.

title: Borders on False Advertising.
text:
This toy is cool, but nowhere near as cool as the hype. Most of the advertised features are bogus.

As others have pointed out, the droid makes no sounds; all the sound comes from your phone. It's also small and the head falls off frequently.

The "holographic communication" is a joke. All it does is play a video on your phone. The toy does nothing.

As far as I can tell, there is nothing adaptive about its personality.

Finally, it doesn't even come with its own charger, only a micro USB cable to plug into a computer. Don't use your phone's charger, the instructions warn against using a power source that provides more than 500mA.

title: You'll have a BALL with BB-8
text:
I've been reading a number of reviews here about the video being misleading (which I disagree with) and I'd like to add my experience so far, having purchased one on Sept. 4th.

No, the sounds do not come from they toy itself, but I find this to be a non-issue. With as much technology that is packed into this little ball-droid, I don't see how speakers for voice could be expected; especially since they would be muffled by the casing. The sounds coming from the app allow for a louder, more clear audio than in-toy speakers could ever achieve.

As for controlling BB-8, it does take a bit of practice. I found that it took about fifteen minutes for me to get a good grasp on the controls. Adjusting its speed in the settings was helpful; they key is to not go so fast that you lose control. Patrol mode is fun, and although I've read reviews where people stated that it just bumped into things, I didn't find that to be entirely the case. Yes, within small spaces it will bump into objects frequently (by nature of a roaming mode), but it will adjust itself and continue to roam while preforming quirky personality bits. You can also view a variety feedback data of its journey in real time.As for the head: it stays on very well. The attachment is strong and I've only had it pop off once or twice during play (and only when smacking forcefully into an object). When it does separate, BB-8 glows red and will shake in response. Voice control has a variety of commands including a reaction to the famous phrase "It's a trap!". It's very fun to see him react to your voice and takes the toy further than a simple R/C robot. Also, during manual control there are a number of pre-set expressions and actions you can make BB-8 do including: 'yes' and 'no' and 'frustrated' expressions, movement in a square or figure-8, wobbling, and more.

I feel as if a lot of the negative reviewers expect this to be an earth-shatteringly advanced, real-life robot but if you do the proper research, you'll find that it's a well made, functions very well, and is fun to drive around and have small interactions with. At $150 it's not for a casual buyer (I'm sure other companies will release cheap-o versions), but as a HUGE Star Wars fan, I can tell you it's fast become one of my favorite Star Wars items.

The head is a useless magnet that actually makes the little dude look drunk as it is traveling. I expected more for 150 dollars so I returned it. It should have a camera on the droid and a sensor so at the least it would not run into the same wall for 22 mins. Piece of crap. I am giving it 2 stars because of the paint job it is the only thing keeping this thing from a single star

title: This robot is half-baked and boring disappointment
text:
I rarely take the time to write a review. However I shopped around and found what I thought was going to be the perfect gift for my sons birthday. When we received the Sphero BB-8, I was very surprised to see it came without instructions. There are some advertise capabilities on the box, and there are instructions on how to get started. But nothing tells you how to work the robot or what are all of its capabilities. So you have to rely heavily on YouTube videos and the Sphero help page.

When I visited the help page I was surprised to see the people representing the company leaving very rude responses to people. This happen more than once per tickly when people were complaining that at the time Voice Commands in the Android software were not supported. One company representative who went as far to call a customer a "SOD" (whatever that means).

Anyway with regards to the product I am very disappointed with how it operates. When driving the robot is constantly losing its north south east west orientation. Therefore it becomes very difficult to drive soon after you set the orientation. Secondly the choice of commands for both voice and by choosing icons is very limited, and out right boring. Other then being an RC remote controlled vehicle, this robot doesn't really do anything. I'm greatly disappointed with this product, it's really as if the company was not even trying. Maybe they were just trying to be the deadline and get a product to market before Christmas but I would not recommend buying this it is boring and does nothing of any interest. My five-year-old in my eight-year-old were bored with this thing after about 15 minutes. And neither could even drive it very well without having me constantly reorienting the robot.

I strongly recommend Sphero work hard to update this robot to actually do more of entertaining value for children, as well as go onto their own help website and reprimand those who are treating customers rudely.

title: Sent the BB8 back. No value nor does it work like it is advertised. Very misleading to me.
text:
Well its not what it appears. Packaging is first class but that's it. Yes it rolls and that's all. The head falls off. The wheels get clogged up and there is no holographic message sending or receiving as you would think. It makes a few cute head moves and that's it. The sound comes form your cell phone and really sucks the juice out of your cell phone battery. For $150 bucks there should be more value for the price. Maybe someday the product may do something but as of today not much. I really wish I could say something nice about it but it does not do anything.

I kept it our of the box for a couple of hours to charge it and see what it could do. I put it back in the box within the hour of turning it on. I received it as a gift and I really hope I don't hurt my family members feelings but I would want them to do the same thing if it was in reverse. I am sure I can find something for $150 I can use. The instructions are worthless for this thing. Be prepared to search the web for 3 hours while your charging it so you can find out what it does.

title: Seriously Overrated
text:
If you want a toy robot that has all the charm of an RC car, BB8 is the droid you're looking for.... If instead, you're looking for a gadget with some personality and a few surprises, I would recommend Hasbro's Interactive R2D2.

BB8 is basically just an expensive RC toy with a very, very limited AI tied to a surprisingly skimpy set of voice commands. All four of my kids have reported that BB8 compares unfavorably to R2D2 because of the lack of any real interactivity.

I have also run into quality issues, including frequent Android app crashes when using voice command as well as the "holographic" image recording function.

title: but I feel like people need to know what's not really mentioned here
text:
I don't usually write reviews, but I feel like people need to know what's not really mentioned here.
First off, the antennae are fragile. The larger one snapped off and super glue will not hold it on. Does not affect the functionality of the product, just the aesthetic. For 150 bucks, I would expect it to be a little more durable seeing that the product is capable of potentially wandering into dangerous places. The â€œbody" does not take into consideration whether or not the head will fit under certain spaces, making the whole area vulnerable.
The message program is hit and miss, if you angle your device jutst right it is near the same quality as advertised.
Except for these two issues, this thing works just like it is advertised. I give it 3 stars because for 160 bucks, it should be a little better-crafted and ALL functions should be of the same quality as consumers are led to believe.

* Don't be fooled by the marketing hype and made up videos!

** Don't waste your time calling or trying to open a support ticket. If youâ€™re lucky enough to get a response it will not help and then they will simply stop responding.

They know the product is a dud so they simply ignore all support request. There is no warranty as they don't respond. Trying to escalate is a joke... after they acknowledge you have a problem they also stop responding.

Your kids are left with nothing... Don't put then through the pain and agony (unless you enjoy teaching them how bad a company's product and customer service can be....)

It works with a iPhone and Android app. The early versions were a little cumbersome, and it was pretty difficult to guide your BB-8  through the room. Through the magic of regular updates, this toy just gets more and more fun. It works on carpet and hardwood floors. The head is a little easy to knock off but it's also really easy to put back on.  The only downside is that it is small. I'm not sure how large I was hoping it would be; it's not like I expected it to be life-sized.  I did think it was a little bit bigger though. title: No need to manually go into the Blutooth setup like you would with other Blutooth devices
text:
How to connect iOS App to BB-8

To connect to BB8 with your iOS, do these 3 steps:

Download the BB8 App and run the App

If not connected, Reset the Network setting by going into the SETTINGS-GENERAL-RESET-RESET NETWORK SETTINGS. Resetting just the phone and restarting it may not work either. So, you must reset the NETWORK SETTING.

After reboot, go directly into the app and place the phone as close to the BB8 as possible, and make sure that it is on. Once connected thru the App, the firmware update will start automatically. Then the App will go thru a series of practice commands. G'luck.

NOTE: No need to manually go into the Blutooth setup like you would with other Blutooth devices. In fact, that will disconnect the BB8 App.

title: I love BB-8, but I received a defective charging base and had to exchange :(
text:
I love it....but after 3 days of use my charging base quit working, which was a big disappointment. (The reason this gets 4 and not 5 stars) I reached out to the Sphero tech support and heard nothing back, so now I am waiting on my exchange from Amazon. It's a bummer because the BB-8 unit seems to work just fine, it's the base that is defective. I tried someone else's base, as well as placed their BB-8 on my base, so I know for sure it is the charging base that is the problem. When I plug the base in, the lights flash blue once then nothing. I have tried different outlets and wall plugs, all yielding the same results.

Aside from the no-charging issue, BB-8 is a lot of fun. I found letting him run around on Patrol mode is the most entertaining. My friends and co-workers all get a kick out of BB-8. I am also really eager to see what additions and updates are created, Sphero advertises that they have a "Big Future" planned for BB-8.

Some things to note if you are considering this product:
-My BB-8 really struggled on carpet, so if you have only carpeted flooring, this is something to think about.
-BB-8 has a knack for finding all the dirt, lint, grime and hair laying around, so to maintain it I would recommend cleaning it's head wheels after every use. (There are YouTube videos on how to do this effectively)
-Because of the design, I would not recommend use of BB-8 outside.

Pros: it's cute.

title: RC controls are terrible (to be expected from phone based soft controls)
text: Is the "Adaptive Personality" claim a straight up joke? I have no idea how they can claim that. As is, it barely runs on carpet and flips out on hardwood. RC controls are terrible (to be expected from phone based soft controls), and the roam mode quickly gets stuck on a pretty standard carpet. The "holographic" messages are a pathetic, and the damn thing doesn't even beep on it's own, it's all from the phone. I mean, I can't even just set it up to roam without draining my phone battery. I'd be happy if I paid maybe $30 for it, but the price is insane for what it does. Which is, pretty much nothing.

title: Outrageous invasion of your private/personal data
text: This was a Christmas gift and I was really looking forward to playing with it. Might be a fun toy, but I never got that far - the Android app requires outrageous permissions and access to your contact list, photos, documents, location services and pretty much everything else on your device. Further, their TOS and (lack of) privacy policy pretty much give them unfettered access to your data and permits them to share it at will with whomever they choose. I'd post snippets of the rights over your personal information that Sphero/Zero grants to themselves, but there's no way to gain access to a version of the documents you can save or print because they've made it impossible to do that from within the app and there's nothing I can find on their website. If it was good policy, they wouldn't have to hide it. That's about as slimy as it gets. THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO REASON WHY A TOY LIKE THIS SHOULD REQUIRE SUCH INVASIVE DATA PERMISSIONS! E-mails to "management" at the company have yet to receive a reply. If you're a typical facebook drone who never reads a TOS or privacy policy  agreement before clicking "I ACCEPT" and willingly regurgitates every minor detail of your personal life for others to see and companies to sell to others, you're already in the cesspool and have nothing further to lose - have fun. Not for me, thanks, just for the privilege of playing with an expensive toy.

The app is supposed to be compatible with android versions 4.4.2 and later but, clearly, it is not.  If you do not KNOW--FOR SURE--that your device is capable of downloading the BB-8 app, DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS TOY!!!!!!!!!!! [[ASIN:B0107H5FJ6 Sphero BB-8 App-Enabled Droid]]

title: It's a brilliant toy, and there is a ton of fun ...
text:
It's a brilliant toy, and there is a ton of fun to be had with it. However, that's just the thing it ultimately is only a very expensive remote controlled toy. The autonomous explore mode leads to poor BB-8 slamming into walls with alarming frequency and anyone who wants to preserve this as a collectors piece will be loath to have it slam into concrete.
The video of this product being used on a table top is misleading, the BB-8 unit cannot detect edges and will fall. So please don't experiment.
This is a very function realistic remote/app controlled BB-8, it is not a droid that can move around on its own.

Cons: the droid's sound effects come out of your phone/tablet not the droid (although I should have figured this in hindsight, the ads led me to believe the audio was coming out of the droid... somehow). Also, you can't save or send video of the droid projecting holographic messages, the droid has a very short memory as far as the room mapping function in 'patrol' mode and the head can pop off when the droid hits something too hard.. doesn't usually though.

Pros: droid otherwise functions as depicted in the ad. Fun to terrorize cats with it although they recently befriended it, which is less fun..

title: BB-8 is more than just a toy! Program it to do more!
text:
Unlike most people, I did not see the trailer until AFTER I bought this. Originally I wanted an original Sphero Sprk but after seeing that they had a BB-8 one, AND for only $49 on Prime Day, I knew my SW-loving kids would love it even more.

BB-8 Sphero is exactly what I was looking for because it is PROGRAMMABLE, just like a Sphero Sprk, plus all the bonus Star Wars toy features that I now see on the trailer (yes, but it's a shame that the sounds don't come from BB-8 directly and the holographic images are only on your mobile device). The key is to not only download the BB-8 specific app but to download the Sphero Edu app, which allows you to control, program your BB-8 to be way smarter than its pre-programmed self. You can have it react or turn around wherever it bumps into something. You can have your mobile device make BB-8 sounds automatically (or even roar like a Lion) whenever BB-8 starts charging. My 8yo programmed it to run laps around my kitchen island. You can program it to go up to your fish bowl, change colors, and turn around. It's a lot of fun and provides quality STEM-based intro-to-robotics education for my kids.

Make sure you have your mobile device Location AND Bluetooth turned on in order for the Sphero Edu to connect to BB-8. And remember to orient BB-8 via the AIM feature before running your program so it runs relative to your orientation. We are loving it in my household when there's so much more you can do with it than just having it explore (roll aimlessly), go to sleep, etc.

title: Cute, and, that's it.
text:
I bought this on the day it came out, due in part to the hype. Used it that first day, then 2 or 3 times more, then sold it.

First off, it's pretty small. I'm not sure what I expected, but the first thought I had upon opening it was "wow, that's tiny. Not a deal breaker, but that's not usually the first thing you want to think when you get a new toy. The size was something of a limiting factor in my not wanting to turn on the mode where he wanders around - you don't want someone stepping on it.

The smartphone controls work fine, but the app doesn't add anything of real interest. In retrospect it was anpretty big negative for me because the kids couldn't play with it if I wasn't around (they don't have smart phones).

The real nail in the coffin is that it just wasn't much fun. Once you zip him around the room a time or two, the novelty is totally gone. He was pretty useless on our carpet, but even having 1000 sq ft or so of laminate flooring for him to roam around, there was rarely a compelling reason to pull him out of the cradle, short of "hey, check this out".

title: Not worth the hype - horrible controls - poor execution
text: I was excited to get this, yet you soon realize that the horrible controls and lack of functionality start to rear their ugly "wobbly" head and it is not worth the $150. If you have pets that shed, pass on this - as the smooth ball and head will pick up hair immediately, disrupting its functionality, IF you can get the thing to actually roll around. AND if you do - you will soon find out that the controls - though should appear intuitive they are flawed by the stabilization feature - which continuously makes it wobble to right itself. The head pops off with almost every impact and mind you some of those impacts are not really form you intentionally driving it into something. The thing is just plain frustrating to us. Great Star Wars marketing, but poor execution. I rather spend my money on some other Star Wars stuff that sits on my desk for less, because that is exactly what this thing would have done. I returned it.

title: Waste of 150 bucks
text: bought thid for my son's birthday. First off doesn't even come with any instructions. So we open up the box. Download the app, connect bb8. My son plays with it for about 35-40 mins. He puts it on the dock to charge over night. We wake up try to connect bb8 again to the phone. Nothing works, we uninstalled/reinstalled app, reset the toy on the dock with the button, turn off/on blue tooth, reset my phone, downloaded app on other phones nothing worked. Doesn't want to connect. Plus when this piece of crap was working it was super hard to control. When you put it on patrol mode it just hits a wall and stays there. The promo video was misleading. Really disappointed with this product. I don't write much reviews but beware if you are ready to pay 150 bucks for something that is as crappy as this.

title: A drunk little droid whose battery is no more
text: This is a very exciting product idea, but it falls short upon opening the box. Firstly, the ads for this would make you believe the droid itself makes sounds, however, all sounds simply come from the app. The second thing is this droid is more like a drunk little droid, its wobbles all over the place when trying to stop and can barely move on anything but hard floors. Meanwhile the head is gets filled with dust and other wheel clogging items causing the droid to be even less smooth. I will say I am glad you can now purchase replacement heads. Finally, I have had my BB-8 since the first day it was available and now it is completely useless. After not playing with this droid for over a year, I decide to pull it out after some new features were released only to find that it will not hold a charger. I contacted customer support, followed their trouble shooting guide, and when that failed they said sorry its dead and there is nothing I could so now I have a $130 paperweight that twitches in its charger if I plug it in. I maybe got a total of 8 hours of this droid in action (if even that much) before it died forever.

title: I really like my BB-8 App-Enabled Droid!  Lots of Fun!
text:
I really like my BB-8 App-Enabled Droid.

I was able to play with it right out of the box. I know that a lot of people are and were expecting a lot more from this Droid. Okay, the droid would be cooler if it had a camera built in to see from the droids point of view or even better if the droid itself made sounds and noise. So it is not actually a droid as much as a remote controlled ball, and that was all I was really expecting it to be considering the price. The sound comes as bleeps and bloops from the device you choose to use to control your droid, in my case it is my iPhone 6 plus or my iPad mini 3. There are several cool settings on the app that make the droid do things like move in a figure 8 or a square, give you a short burst in speed, say yes or no and a few other neat things. There is also a cool voice control setting that allows you to make your droid do a few little tricks by talking to it through your device. Lights flash in the droid and the head moves in different directions when following your commands. The voice control only seems to work well on my iPad and not so well on my iPhone though.

The droid itself is about 6 inches tall with its head connected. The head is held on to the droid body by the use of a magnet and does fall of it you hit a wall or solid object when moving at a high speed but otherwise stays on well. It is pretty cool that the head stays upright while the rest of the body rolls around and that it turns to face what ever direction the body is moving in. The droid begins to flash red when his head falls of and also beings to make noises through the app. It does not come with any real instructions except for a graphic that uses pictures to tell you to attach the droids head, set it on the charger and download the app. The app will give instructions on how to operate BB-8.

Like I said, I really like my BB-8. The only thing that would be better is if it were more "droid-like." It doesn't learn anything or interact with the controller. Other than this, it was a great toy at a great price and anything a really cool collectors item. I would have given the item a 5 star rating if the price were not so high.

title: It was a lot of fun and my family and I enjoyed it greatly
text:
I bought this a while back, but returned it after a couple weeks (best buy elite member). It was a lot of fun and my family and I enjoyed it greatly. However, it was difficult for the fun to last more than a few seconds because the head kept popping off. You barely bump something and there goes his head. I spent the majority of the time chasing down his head only to have it knocked off immediately after. And no.. it had nothing to do with my driving the thing.

Also, another let down is that "hologram" app on the phone was very clunky and just not that good at all. I tried it out a couple of times and didn't bother with it anymore.

Also, the bb8 has no speakers .. the sound comes through your phone. That is stupid.

It would have also have been nice if you could see through the eyes of bb8 on the screen of your device.

It was a love hate relationship. I loved playing with BB-8, but I also got very angry with having to clean the gunk out from under his wheels (under his head) and picking his itty bitty head off the floor.

This BB-8 is very likeable though. I got attached immediately and I know this sounds weird... but he felt like a part of the family, haha. I actually felt bad and guilty when I returned him to the store...Like I was giving away the family dog.

I miss this little guy, but I think he is waaay overpriced

title: Awesome Little Droid!
text:
I'm sure that by now everyone already knows about this cute little droid, so I wont bore you with the specifications about it. It's a lot of fun to roll around the house, or to just watch it roam around by itself (and bang into quite a few walls along the way). Somehow this little droid comes across as a real Star Wars droid come to life with how he interacts with everything around him.

The app that controls BB-8 is put together well, and it's very easy to use for almost any age. I do like how the developers have made it so BB-8 can receive future updates to his software. This means there will be new things added to BB-8 every once in a while to give him new actions, sounds, etc.

The fact that I now have BB-8 from the new Star Wars movie in my home is really neat, but the part that makes it great is that it moves and looks almost exactly like how the movie trailers show BB-8.

Overall this is a great little droid, and I think that anyone who is a fan of Star Wars, or is just attracted by BB-8's cute looks should buy him. Even though it is a little pricey, it's worth it in my opinion.

title: Great fun, great looks, great laughs, horrific battery.
text: The build quality is outstanding, the app is simple and easy to use, the controls are intuitive and clean (after about an hour, once you really figure them out), and the emotes BB-8 can do are hilarious, cute, and very movie accurate. The charging dock is high quality as well. Everything about the toy itself is pretty flawless when you're using it. The big downer is the battery life: it's hilariously bad. It's as if the toy is powered by a single camera battery. Apparently it has a 3/1 charge/play ratio (3 hours of charging = 1 hour of play), but it's more like 3/0.5. It feels like I have to charge it after every time I use it. But, overall, it's fun. You're probably not buying to to play with every single day. Think of it as a collectable that leaves you shelf once or twice a week. If you like collecting things like this, then definitely pick it up. If you're looking for an RC car type toy for little kids to play with every day. then it's not for you.

title: ... BB-8 and then after 10 minutes I was very disappointed. The three main issues I think for the ...
text:
I felt excited when I received my Sphero BB-8 and then after 10 minutes I was very disappointed. The three main issues I think for the BB-8 is
1. Application. You have to keep your app on all the time in order to do anything with the toy, and the moment you exit the app or turn off the phone, BB-8 stops, even if it was in patrol mode.
2. Sound. The Sphero BB-8 doesn't make any sound AT ALL, the app is the one making droid noises, and that's just lame
3. The head. The head piece just keeps falling off, however the body will just keep going w/o the head. So if the head unfortunately fell off at some hidden space, good luck finding it because the body wouldn't be near it.

Other than those, it's easy to control the the movement, and its fun for the first 10 minutes after I received it. I can't really justify the price I paid for it for just 10 minutes of fun so I returned mine.

title: I am amazed by how precise I can control a moving ball
text:
I have owned and played with this little droid for a week and it still makes me laugh and smile. At first I was running BB-8 into walls and making awful turns but after some practice and learning how to control it's speed, I was able to make very precise turns and flawless maneuvering through natural and man-made obstacles.

I am amazed by how precise I can control a moving ball. I love the way BB-8's head weaves back and forth depending on how I'm moving it. And seeing the head pointed down at full speed is hilarious. The pre-programmed actions are pretty cool and funny to. Having it react No or Yes is awesome. Seeing it shy away. Giving it voice commands and having it react to that is neat. And I love how Sphero promises to upgrade the firmware to add new features, especially after The Force Awakens premieres since we don't really know what BB-8 does yet.

If you can find this little droid, get it! This is definitely a must have and has lasting ability. Especially with the aforementioned future updates. It's hard to get tired of it. And if you do, let it go on Patrol and have it learn your surroundings. It's my coolest looking Star Wars toy in my possession. It's actually my coolest toy in general.

title: High level tech, low level product
text:
I bought this for my girlfriend at the mall tonight. The technology is really neat, the app and all the control features are incredibe, the movements are realistic and it's overall a great concept for a toy that is probably several years away from being viable.

The first huge flaw is the size. For the "real BB8," he's extremely diminuitive. The second big aesthetic flaw is the level of detail on the toy itself. It's literally just cheap looking sticker graphics that look like they would easily come off.

Onto the craftsmanship. With BB8's propensity for running into everything, even on patrol mode, they probably should have made him, you know, capable of withstanding those inevitable collissions. O

ne of the antennas literally broke off within 15 minutes. They're about a quarter of the thickness of a toothpick, and half the durability. For a $150 toy, you would think the antennas could at least be as sturdy as the black series $20 combo toy that comes with Rey. Speaking of the black series BB8, which would individually be valued at around $10, the level of detail on that figure is easily three times better than this "real" BB8.

I get that we're supposed to be paying for the tech, but I just can't see the point if the BB8 itself is going to be so cheaply made. The magnet head is constantly falling off, not secure on the figure at all. It's basically designed to break a lot. We haven't even had ours for an hour yet and we already need to return it. My girlfriend literally cried over the antenna breaking on her gift so soon. Please do better.

title: Never worked properly
text: Never worked properly. Husband down loaded software to his phone multiple times, called customer service - not able to help besides tell him to re-download software.  Really disappointed in the amount of time and effort to set up this toy. We cannot return this since it was purchased under the holiday return policy guidelines.  Buy this in a store where you can take it back if the software will not sync,  Good luck!

title: He's pretty rad if you know what he is and is not.
text:
The biggest complaint that people seem to have is that there are no sounds emitted from the droid, all sound effects come from your phone via the app. The video promotion for this droid was arguably misleading. It's a legitimate complaint for people to have, though I was already aware of this prior to purchasing.

With that out of the way, I love this little dude. In the spirit of full disclosure, I am a Star Wars guy, so let that be your warning that I may be a tad biased. It controls competently with the app and it moves faster than I had assumed it would be capable of. The novelty of his semi-stationary head is still a marvel of engineering every time I put him on the floor to terrorize the family cat. His free roam mode makes it apparent that there's not much going on in terms of complex spatial logic. But, really, without on board sensors there's really no way for a device like this to avoid obstacles without running into them first. I also really like that, with a push of the demo button, when he's in his charging dock he will glow and move his head around in ways that almost seem intentional, which is adorable. Even though I can get over the fact that he has no on board speakers it would have been awesome if he had a 3 minute timed demo mode while in the charging dock that would periodically emit beeps and chirps while he was looking around (which would require a speaker on the charging dock). I think his little holo message feature (which is all handled in the App in case you were unaware) is such an underwhelming feature that it probably would have been better to not even have it. It is kind of expensive but I've spent more on grown up toys that did less, so to me I don't think his price is an issue.

In the end it's a pretty simple decision. Do you like pointless tech? Do you like Star Wars?

text:
The toy comes really well packaged and the packaging feels sturdy and really well made. Inside the box you'll find the bb8 unit , the charging station and micro USB cable as well as instruction on how to download the control software for your cellphone so you can enjoy your toy. After installing the software on your cellphone you will get to fully control your bb8 there is few modes that either allow you to control bb8 , pre-made commands, and patrol mode where your bb8 will wander around and map the terrain around him.

Generally speaking I really enjoyed the toy , it's a cool gadget for kids and adults to play around with and for starwars fans to enjoy their own private bb8. If you are looking for a cool toy that will keep your kids occupied look no further !

- all of the sounds come from your phone
- the hologram message function is only on your phone (it's kind of stupid)
- he doesn't really learn he bumps into stuff and rolls the other way and if you have him do patrolling then he just keeps bumping into the things and trying to find a new way around but it's not 'entertaining'
- it's not really a 'droid', it's more a remote controlled rolling device.

Anyhow - completely honest opinion: if you are not a DIE HEARD fan who doesnt care that the functionality is NOTHING to do with what you are imagining, you wouldnt want to spend 128 dollars on this, but it's COOL ;)

title: All in all though this is an awesome droid toy and very fun to play with
text:
I just received BB-8 today and I am thrilled with its intuitive functionality. Simple and elegant instructions (merely 4 steps) and you are off and patrolling with your new droid.

Some things to consider on the app side would be improving the voice recognition part and additional voice commands
Also, I wish the sounds actually came from the droid and not the app - that would make it much more enjoyable, but as of now you loose some of the immersion of the whole experience (which is why this is a 4 and not a 5 star review).

All in all though this is an awesome droid toy and very fun to play with.

title: Bb-8 is awesome for die hard fans.
text:
If you truly love starwars and understand what a sphero is you will not be disappointed. Die hard starwars collectors pay this much for high quality inanimate replicas. I bought this knowing that this is the most accurate bb-8 replica available currently. It didn't hurt to know that he is also a sphero 2.0 that is pretty tough. His body is 100% waterproof and if you charge him fully he lasts about an hour. Just as any lithium battery device the harder you are on charging cycles the less your battery will last. His head is not meant to get wet but i did drop it in water and other than it leaking for a bit all was fine. I have heard of some having issues after falling from heights but my has fell off tables and down carpeted stairs without any reprocussions. Seeing as this may be the most introactive starwars droid other than hasbros more expensive r2 unit, i give it 5/5. I got mine at bestbuy and found a 10% off coupon online making my droid about 142 after tax.

May the force be with you!

title: Reskinned sphero with all the flaws
text: The original sphero and this are very hyped up, but playing with it is not fun. To drive it, you need to calibrate what it sees as "forward" vs "forward" in the app pretty much every time it rolls the length of a room or hits anything. Otherwise, when you move the onscreen joystick it doesn't go in the right direction. The controls are very inexact because it's a ball with wheels inside it that make it accelerate, not move at a constant speed or turn predictably like an RC car. The ball does not make any sounds. The sounds come from your smartphone. Same for voice control - you're speaking into your phone with all the excitement of Siri or Google Now. That really takes you out of the fun fantasy of it being a droid "companion". Also, the hologram video feature is hyped almost to being false advertising since there's no camera in the sphero. It just uses your smartphone camera.

title: Great for kids aged 5-12!  Adults, keep your lofty expections in check.  ;)
text:
Sure, it would be nice if it had AI and some other features, but for my five-year-old nephew, BB-8 is perfect. Having just recently seen The Force Awakens, he's now a Star Wars junkie and BB-8 is one of his favorite Christmas gifts. He's very much enjoying learning the toy's capabilities and limitations (as his his Dad, I suspect); the mini-droid and its app have a good learning curve for ages 5-12, IMO.

At the time of this writing, the price for BB8 is $129, but on 12/19/16, when I purchased it, it was $99. Not sure what that's about, but obviously I've got no complaint about the price break. Right time at the right place, I suppose.

Since I'm writing this review the day of Carrie Fisher's death, I'll add that it's mighty painful to see her depart the mortal coil. A great raconteur with a fantastic sense of humor, she will be very sorely missed. I hope a trusted friend or family member will be taking good care of her charismatic dog, Gary.

title: Dont get it. Save yourself some money and be sensible
text: Will drain your phone in no time and basically is just a ball that rolls by itself but mostly not where you want it to go. You'll be bored with it after a few days. Just get a regular ball, go outside and kick it about. Will provide you far more pleasure. On top of this my bb-8 gave up on life after a few months. No use and no quality.

title: Too expensive for what little it does.
text:
This is way overpriced for what you're actually getting. We purchased this and a sphero for our kids last Christmas. They were about the same price. We'd just seen Episode 7, and are a family of Star Wars fanatics, so we were all excited.

After 20 minutes, my 8 year old (whom we bought this for) was following my 6 year old and his sphero around, asking to play with it.

This BB8 looks cool, but simply doesn't DO much. You can drive it, but if it hits the wall, there are high odds its head will pop off. You can send it to explore, so it'll wander around your house (again, though, the head falls off so easily, you have to follow it around putting it back on). You can watch/create videos (BB8 calls them holographic messages) on your phone or iPad. You can tell your BB8 to do a few things, assuming you can get the voice recognition to work.

That's pretty much it. I don't think we ever found games, nor is there any sort of programming capability. It's very expensive for what you actually get. The sphero is a much better investment for a kid. In fact, my husband "bought" BB8 from our son so he could have his own sphero, because that's how awesome the other robot is.

If you're a Star Wars fan with money to burn, and all you really want is a mini BB8 to look at or occasionally wander your house, this robot is probably fine for you. If you have kids who want to DO stuff with their robot, this isn't the robot for you at all.

title: Disappointing, when stacked against  Hasbro's Artoo
text: Picked one up today(9/4) at BB&B, after reading another review and refusing to pay the scalpers prices. Anyway it was a fun afternoon in the office. The  issue I have is it doesn't work on the carpet at my home. Just sits there. According to the log from patrol mode it thinks it's moved but he just sits there :( HE also couldn't "map" a TV tray, just kept banging into the edges. Heard about voice, but it's not supported on Android - and over all does less than a normal Sphero. At my house he has become a $150 animatronic paperweight. Having both BB-8 and the big voice activated R2-D2  (http://www.amazon.com/Star-Wars-R2-D2-Interactive-Astromech/dp/B002KHN23S/ref=pd_sim_21_1?ie=UTF8&refRID=07A8N3CH7HD6SDMR4HXN&dpSrc=sims&dpST=_AC_UL160_SR160%2C160_) Artoo well. Wins. He's programmable, plays games and has a bunch of easter eggs, including a retelling of Empire Strikes Back, from his perspective while the Imperial March plays. Artoo can also handle my living room carpet.

title: The Real Deal
text:
Purchased this for my 5 y.o. who is obsessed with Star Wars and BB-8 in particular. In a word, this thing rocks. The packaging is solid (not that that matters to a toddler, but it makes you feel a little better about dropping so much cash on a toy). The droid itself is the real highlight and we weren't disappointed (after we got over the diminutive size). Watching BB-8 explore our house is mesmerizing. It is so much like the movie droid it's uncanny. The app that controls the droid is well thought out and works great, although it has difficulty recognizing my son's voice. I say that's his problem, not Sphero's.

Regarding the size. It's small. Like really small. That's everyone's first reaction when they see it. But whatever disappointment there may be with the size quickly disappears when BB-8 starts moving around and beeping and bopping. My son has a bunch of the larger 13" Star Wars figures, so I explained to him that BB-8 is the perfect size for those toys, which it is.

In summary, this is an awesome toy. Yes, it's pricey. But if you're a Star Wars Force Awakens fan, or your kids are, you will love this.

title: Although it has some noticeable drawbacks, BB-8 is still a totally neat piece of tech.
text:
A great item for any Star Wars fan, or someone who just likes interesting gadgets. It is made well and responds well to commands. I primarily only ever use the drive and autonomous mode. The augmented reality videos are a neat feature but have zero lasting appeal and are not great quality either (the augmented reality features on my 3DS are better). It would have been nice if this model featured some on-board speakers and/camera. I think people would have still gladly paid a higher price for those added features. The build is durable and well crafted, although the head does come off from time to time while rolling. I think this is partially due to the dust and dirt that gets lodged in the wheel mechanic. That is also tricky to clean. I have not seen any of the advertised intelligence or learning traits since I have had it. The lasting appeal is short, at least in this household, but it looks nice and is a good conversation piece. I was hesitant to buy one for months but I had gift money piling up so it seemed time to pull the trigger.

Overall, I would still recommend it to any Star Wars or technology fans as I mentioned at the start of the review. It's a really fun piece and half of the excitement for me future potential. As it is app driven it can be updated wirelessly (although that obviously doesn't help the lack of camera or speaker). I think of this as a bit of a prototype and hope they come out with an updated, amazing model some time in the next few years.

title: Kids' favorite Christmas gadget
text:
Purchased this as a surprise Christmas gift for a daughter (11) and a son (9). Out of all the Christmas gifts, this is the one they have played with the most.

Within minutes of seeing this little guy, they had downloaded the software to their iPad 2 minis and were off and running. The daughter was a wiz controlling the unit within 15 minutes having it move in and out of various obstacles; for the son, it took about 2 hours for him to get a good level of control so that he wasn't smashing the unit into walls and other obstacles.

They've had no issues controlling the unit even as they switch who controls the unit (just place the iPad near the unit and it will take control); battery life has been plenty long for every session.

Only con has been the antennae -- since the device is small it will try to go under a standard couch. While the head can come off, many times the antennae can be bent to a funny angle. There's no functionality with the antennae - it's more of the aesthetic look, so a minor con.

If they were under $100 I'd probably have at least two running around the house -- maybe 3 as the dogs seem to enjoy chasing the little droid around as well.

title: Item won't connect, poor tech support
text:
This product worked as described the first time out of the box, the second time I used it the controls seemed a little off. But because I purchased this item before the release of Star Wars The Force Awakens I decided to wait for the post movie update to see if that would improve my experience.

Well as you can tell by my rating it did not. I updated the app on my phone, and tried to connect to my BB8 droid. Nothing but an error message saying no droid detected. So I tried my other devices, I received the same responses. Nothing it would not connect! Just an expensive paperweight. I followed the trouble shooting tips provided by the app. Still nothing works, so it says to contact Sphero technical support. I sent two seperate emails, which I still have not received a response from either a month later.

In fact, I did not receive contact from Sphero until I posted something on their facebook page. I guess they do not want others to see I am having problems. Tech support gave me a few things to try, none of which helped. Then mysteriously tech support disappears again. I have asked them to contact via phone which I am still awaiting their phone call since they do not have a customer support number of their own apparently. I fear at this point there is a malfunction of some sort of its internal hardware. At this point I really wish I could just return this item due to the fact that it doesn't work and the poor state of Sphero's customer support. But apparently Amazon on accepts returns 1 month from purchase date.

Buyer be warned.

text: What a disappointment!  My son played with it for an hour, never touched it again. It was his Christmas present.  (We are both big-time Star Wars fans). He didn't even notice it being gone the next day when I put it away, then sent it back to Amazon. I give it one star for a truly beautiful packaging, likely worth $140. title: Wonderful!
text:
This little guy is great. Right out of the box he was already raring to go and syncing with my phone! The messages on the patrol mode event log are hilarious (it marked my ferret as an aggressive life form and my boyfriend got marked with a Stormtrooper mask on the map twice). A few things: I see a lot of people are complaining about a few things that really are more their fault. First it's easy enough to make sure your phone or tablet is compatible with the Sphero before you spend your money, simply look at the website. It lists the specs your device needs right there. If nothing else the app won't even show up for you in the play store if it isn't compatible. You can download the app for free even before you buy so try it, you have nothing to lose. Second, yeah it's going to catch things off your floor as it rolls around...so clean your floors. It isn't hard, although with pets I can understand having a bit of a problem. If you're having trouble connecting simply reinstall the app, accept the terms again, turn Bluetooth on and off, and it should be okay. Besides if you go and purchase something with high expectations you're going to end up disappointed anyway. It'd a good idea to read reviews on sites like this too. As for the limited stuff it does now, Sphero has already said they plan on doing more with BB8 in the future so there ya go. It's called patience.

Anyway, the driving is fun, the actions you can command it to do are hilarious...we made a video that had it looking like it was dancing to a Psyclon Nine song. Haven't tried the hologram messaging yet but I'm not too big into that anyway. The main draw for me is that it's cute and the fact that it keeps marking my boyfriend as a bad guy is a bonus.

I highly recommend it, although for kids I might go with the cheaper Hasbro version, especially if they are the sort to be rough on their toys. This little guy is tough but for the amount of money I wouldn't get too risky with it. Oh and it works just fine on my carpet.

title: Helped my six year old learn programming. Pretty freaking cool.
text:
First things first: I'm a huge Star Wars fan. My kids are named after Star Wars characters. From the moment I saw this thing, I had to have it.
I'm writing this review several months after the initial release because we love it so much and although it felt like a random toy splurge at the time we bought it, it's turned out to be so much more.

BB-8 is very well-built. My boys are six and two, they've rolled it all over our house, it's fought my army of chihuahuas quite bravely, it's been dropped a couple times - no problems. Not even a broken antenna.

The built-in Sphero app allows you to drive BB-8, ask him simple questions, and send him out on patrol. It's pretty simple, pretty fun, and even my two year old can drive BB-8 - it's that intuitive.

Third-party apps make this thing shine. We found an app that allows for drag-and-drop programming and my six year old has fallen in love. He can change BB-8's color to pretty much anything the LED set can handle, make him respond with all kinds of kooky commands, and drive him in increasingly strange shapes and patterns. If for nothing else, getting my kid excited about programming makes BB-8 worth the money and definitely worth a five-star review.

title: Barely functional. Not even remotely worth the price.
text:
- Rather than an App-Enabled Droid, it should be labelled as an App-Required Droid. If you don't have a device supported by the very limited software, you cannot use this "Droid" at all.
- I found "Driving" to be very confusing and was already frustrated with the device so I didn't bother trying to work it out.
- "Patrol" basically involves the droid running into everything over and over again. It also requires that your iOS / Android device keep the app running constantly with Bluetooth enabled.
- The droid and charging station seem to have various error codes expressed through flashing lights, but there's no manual anywhere so good luck figuring out what everything means.
- Charging the droid is a crap shoot. I thought that placing the droid on its pedestal and seeing a flashing blue light indicated a charging state, but that is often not the case.
