text: This little (8 or 10 inches) robot has been a favorite of my sons.  He loves being able to control it with an app on his phone.  It was easy to download and use.  Charging the unit is fairly easy.  It has a lot of difficulty rolling on any type of carpet, and rolls the head of the magnet center.  To get it to reset, we have to set the whole unit on the base, then the head will adhere to the magnet inside the body.

title: I prefer a physical remote but this toy is still great. Once you get used to it
text: As you probably have read before, bb8 is controlled by an app rather than an actual remote. I prefer a physical remote but this toy is still great.  Once you get used to it, driving it is a lot of fun. The controls will always be a little tricky but since it's essentially a ball you're driving then that's to be expected.  Also, being app controlled, the sound only comes from your device. I thought this would take away from the experience as well but it really hasn't. My children get a kick out of the messaging mode as well. Bb8 also has some preset commands such as to drive in a square, figure 8, etc. These are great. I only hope that sphero adds more of these commands in future app updates. Some comment that the head falls off too easily but the key to that is too not bump into too many things.  The big question I asked before buying was is this worth around $150? If you're an adult who likes Star Wars and will enjoy this along with your kids then yes.

title: Sphero was Fun for a Week
text: I purchased Sphero out of curiosity. After using it for a week, I found a couple of things bothersome. It must be used on a hard flat surface (hardwood floor, linoleum, short-cut fiber carpet, etc.) to work well. If used on normal carpeting, Sphero gets mired down and will not roll. Also, Sphero has a problem with floor transitions, like going from hardwood floor to an area rug, and will not always make the transition. Sphero's head is attached magnetically, and, if Sphero makes a sudden stop, like hitting a chair leg, the head goes flying. Sphero now mostly sits in his charging stand unused and collecting dust.

title: The BEST Star Wars Force Awakens BB-8 toy on the market for many reasons.
text:
The box looks special, like you are getting a major collector piece. If you love Star Wars, its a fantastic piece to pick up. The presentation of the BB-8 is probably the best packing I have ever seen for a toy. Opening it up, BB-8 is built and ready to go. The app is fairly quick to download and get going, from open to start it took about 3-4 minutes to get BB-8 to roll around from the package.

He is small in comparison to other BB-8 models, but to be honest it works in the favor of being small that he functions better. The technology is great, as its the original technology from the BB-8 in Force Awakens. The functions of the controls through the app require a bit of practice, but after about 10 minutes of rolling around you can easy move him how you want. The app offers a bunch of stuff that I didn't see many others mention. He can do motions at a push of a button that act sort of like a reaction to something. If you hit one he can spin around, quickly move forward, look down, shake his head, and more. Its really gives this BB-8 an attitude.

On carpet he moves, not as good as a flat surface. This is something that is expected with any Sphero ball. His head moves great with his body. I didn't have a lot of issues of the top piece falling off. He is very durable and the magnet really holds in place well.

Also the battery is great, I didn't play with him until he died. I think getting a hour on a battery is perfectly fine for him. If you want him to patrol maybe that would be different. The patrol is unique, he really just moves around and bumps into walls and objects, acts as if he looks at it and then moves away. The batteries are no replaceable, but I am sure there will be something in the future just in case a battery needs to be changed out. Sure Sphero will offer a service on that. I would prefer a battery like this over double AA or AAA can get pricey in the long run, in which the Hasbro model has.

As for kid functionally, its not as easy has the Hasbro model which is cheaper. However, I think the durable is where the Sphero stands out. If you want to spend 80 dollars on that model, I don't see it lasting as long. You get what you pay for.

Last, the sound is fine. I know people want it to come from the actual BB-8, but with the Sphero its sealed. It makes for a better durable BB-8, the sound is just fine coming out of the phone. You could bluetooth the sound to external bluetooth speakers likely that is further away from you. Just a thought on that.

I think this is a great toy, probably one of the best Star Wars Force Awakens products out there.

title: So fun
text:
Everything about this screams high quality. From the packaging to the details on BB-8 and even on his charging station. He is extremely well packaged! And The box he comes in is very nice. Not your typical cheap cardboard box. I would recommend keeping it. I can't bring myself to throw it away. I feel like how a product is packaged speaks volumes about the quality of and the care that went into the product. BB-8 himself is very sleek. He is plastic, but not a flimsy type that feels fragile. He appears to be sturdy and well built.

He comes with a USB cord, a charging base, and of course BB-8 himself all fit securely inside a styrofoam inlay inside the box to keep BB-8 secure during shipping. A base to plug the USB into is not included, but I have those things lying around my house in mass quantities so it didn't bother me. However if you wish to plug him in and charge him via a wall socket you will need one so keep that in mind.

He is interactive and loads of fun to play with and watch. He's very expressive and animated. He really makes you feel like he is more than a toy. I fell in love with him right off the bat, and so will anyone else I am sure of it.

The app is easy to use and has a user friendly interface.

BB-8 is reasonably fast and moves effortlessly and flawlessly on hard surfaces and pretty well on carpet depending on how thick your carpet is. I found that he moves better on my area rug than on my actual carpet, but even on the carpet he manages to get around, albeit at a slower pace that takes him a bit more effort, but he does it nonetheless. (I suppose it helps that he is a sphere shaped object) his head rotates smoothly, and he is is very agile. I have read that for some, there are issues with his head popping off, but this has yet to happen to me.

He can't do tons of things, but what he can do he does very well.

I do wish he made sounds and that they didn't just come from the app itself, so that is a small downside.

The holographic video messages are fun, my kids really enjoy recording themselves and watching it play back, and I think it is a cute feature.

You might look at this and think it is overpriced, but keep in mind that sphero is a quality brand and Star Wars is a pop culture icon. Combine the two and it can be a bit pricey, but I have seen Star Wars figures, toys and even posters sell for far more than this. Plus you get a fun, interactive experience and a cute new friend to play with. That being said, I definitely feel like it is worth the money and I do not regret my purchase. It's even $10 cheaper on here than it was at Best Buy where I purchased this for my daughter.

If you're a Star Wars fan, a tech fan, a sphero fan- you will love this!.

title: Immersive and fun

But it is much more than that. If you're a Star Wars fan, and saw episode VII, this is a very immersive product. The sounds, the way it behaves, feels like it's alive, like it has a bit of will of its own. If you're a true fan, and specially like gadgets and such, the cost benefit its amazing, you'll definitely have fun. If you have pets, than they're in for a treat. :)

title: Very neat to a lifetime fan.
text:
I first saw The Empire Strikes Back on VHS when I was four/five years old ('91/'92). My Grandmother let me pick it out at the local video rental store. I vaguely remeber choosing it based on the cover.
I had her rent it two more times over the next year before I realized Star Wars was a Trilogy.

I've loved Star Wars ever since. Even in the sixth grade, when I saw The Phantom Mencace, I cringed a bit, but the series endured for me.

I grew up on Star Wars. I had/have tons of action figures and vehicles. I made my own movies, as a kid, with friends and action figures, on an old shoulder mounted Sony VHS recorder camera.

If I had this BB-8 back then, I would have been completely enamored. Whether it was action figures, vehicles, light sabers, or video games, Star Wars merchandise always made my Birthday list. I saw this product this morning on IGN and added it to my Birthday list this year (end of this month.) It was extraordinarily nostalgic for me. Star Wars hasn't been on my list in quite a while (28 years old in a couple weeks)

To my total surprise, my wonderful Wife brought BB-8 home for me this afternoon. She's adored him since Star Wars Celebration, and she has never seen a single film (just won't budge.)

Overall, it's a really neat piece from Star Wars. I'm happy to have BB-8 sitting on my desk. More importantly though, my Wife likes him and my 15 month-old daughter kept saying Beebee [BB] (baby) which, coincidentally is my favorite word she says at the moment, while she was mezmerized by the fact that its head was turning on its own in its charging station.

I Can't wait to play Battlefront on my PS4 and go see The Force Awakens this Winter...very pleased that Abrams is Directing.
Thanks for the "droid", Star Wars, Sphero, Disney, etc. Five-star product, in my opinion.

I recommend the Hasbro one, it feels more realistic and makes noise on its own. Also works on carpeted surfaces.  The video was very misleading to the features, am I very disappointed for the amount this costed.

title: Realistic Movement - App Generates Sound and Video
text: Purchased for 12 year old daughter.  Fun, Fun, Fun!  Will work with iPod Touch, iPad, iPhone.  All sounds and video come from free downloadable app NOT from BB-8.  You grant app access to microphone, camera, and speakers on your iPod Touch.  You record video through app and it transforms it into hologram looking 2 dimensional video that you view - as you view BB-8 through the camera on your device - and line up your device with BB-8 to make it look like BB-8 is generating the images.  Some fun preloaded hologram looking video messages from a storm trooper and about the X-wing fighter and C3PO.  Tricky to get the hang of driving BB-8 using your finger on the surface of the iPod Touch.  My daughter took 15-20 minutes to start to get the hang of it - even after an hour still tricky - head of BB-8 only falls off when you run into furniture.  BB-8 doesn't run on the short shag nylon carpet I have.  Runs well on hard flooring.  After a few days of driving I think my daughter will be able to control it better.  BB-8's body does light up - not when driving - when starting messaging mode - when you play video on your iPod.  Head is kept attached to body by magnets.  Movement is realistic - head usually stays on top of the rotating body - sometimes stays on side depending on speed of turns.

title: A Little Ball of Fun!
text:
I bought this for my son and I for Christmas and am very pleased with it. I read several of the lower star reviews and I am happy to say that it is a ball of fun! It does exactly what I expected and does it pretty well. My kid is 14 and he mastered the app quickly.
The little droid isn't "perfect", but he isn't a cgi or movie prop. He is a toy. A pretty high tech toy, but a toy nonetheless and I feel many of the negative reviews expected him to be a sentient little dude rather than a toy.
He is perfect and we love him.

title: Star Wars Toys - now with Spyware!
text:
I'm a big Star Wars fan so I thought it was really neat when someone purchased this for me as a gift for a special occasion. It's a disaster.

First off, this looks way more impressive in the video than real life. It doesn't even include a charger that plugs into the wall, just a usb one.

Second, it wasn't even compatible with 90% of the phones, ipads, kindles and other devices I had lying around the house, even some of the ones it was supposed to be. My mother's samsung phone was the only thing that would even let me attempt to install the BB-8 app. Why I can't use my PC to control it, I don't know.

Third, finally and most importantly it loads your phone up with spyware. I finally get to the google play/app store and the conditions of installing the app to control this thing include access to (I'm copying this verbatim):

BB-8 App Enabled Droid needs access to:
- Identity
- Location
- Photos/Media/Files
- Camera
- Microphone
- Wi-fi Connection Information
-Bluetooth Connection Information
-Device ID and call information

Yeah, so why does a toy designed for a 10 year old need access to every aspect of my identity, wi-fi, pictures, my phone records? Answer - it doesn't, it just needs bluetooth, the rest is so it can better load your phone up with spyware. DECLINE. Will be returning for a refund. I really don't need more text spam and telemarketers calling me, let alone when someone had the decency to spend $100 or whatever this costs. At minimum, they should advertise that the app for this is the digital equivalent of a full body cavity search, which they do nowhere.

Not Recommended.

title: Get your own mini droid! w/updates!
text:
sold everywhere so no point paying more then retail.

It's not quite as responsive as I expected it to be, and I haven't figured out how to make it peek around corners like in the commercial.

It's a lil more then I wanted to pay, but seeing that a non Star Wars version is $20 less, it's a decent toy.

It's glossy finished, and about the size of an orange. I wished it could been bigger, like the size of a basketball.

It runs great on carpet and tiled floors, but it lacks the power to go from my kitchen to my living room. The tile is a lil bit lower then the carpet, and that makes all the difference when he follows me into the kitchen and is unable to get out!
-update//- the ball portion doesn't work with sphero 2.0 accessories or its apps for that matter.

I haven't figured out how to keep him from falling off the coffee table. I am using "explore" and that will hopefully make BB8 learn his surroundings better.
-update//- with more time spent on this "droid" I have finally figured out how to keep bb8 from falling off a coffee table. The limits of the so called AI is actually on the app itself.
-on the ground, bb8 will learn to avoid obstacles by bumping into them once or twice, "mapping" the obstacles in the app as more time is given to her.
-to keep bb8 from falling off a coffee table, you'd have to train it. It won't detect that's there's danger in front of her and not fall off the table. She will always fall off. To stop this, place books or TV remote or dvd cases around the edge of the coffee table. After bb8 has run into them, go ahead and remove the "blockade," bb8's mapping system will remind her that the edges have obstacles.

Because the movie is under wraps and Lucafilm doesn't want spoilers, the droid has limited features. Hopefully when the movie comes out, a new patch will be made with references from the movie!

title: he looked bored. In the end
text: My husband was beyond excited when he saw the advertisement videos so I jumped on getting him one of these for his birthday.  He was so excited when it arrived, opened the box and started to play with it.  5 minutes later, he looked bored.  In the end, there isn't any real functionality to it.  The sounds come from the app, patrol mode isnt really anything much and worst of all, it didn't work on our carpets at all.  They're thin carpets more for traction than fluff and BB8 just completely stopped.  Given that we have them all over and we aren't going to pick up the area rugs every time we take this toy out, its basically useless.  Great advertising for a sub-par product.  Ours went back, not with the $150 price tag in the slightest.

title: This is a pretty neat too and I don't regret the purchase
text:
This is a pretty neat too and I don't regret the purchase. However there are some things that I thought anyone looking to purchase this should know.

- The droid itself does not make noise. all sound effects come from the phone, and not the droid itself.
- 'patrol' mode is not that impressive, at least so far. he does tend to run into the same walls a lot. I'm hoping he will learn but this does not seem likely.
- He does have some issues with deeper carpets, but seems to work well on thinner carpets. He seems to work best on tile, linoleum, and wood floors.
- The controls are taking me a bit longer to learn than I had anticipated. I'm not sure if its me or if the device is not that responsive.
- He can ONLY be controlled by your phone.

Overall a decent Star Wars collectible but were it not for the unique look and branding of the toy its rating would be lower. Still a fun purchase, but a bit overpriced at its MSRP of $150 american. Not a bad toy if you can find it considerably cheaper, I would think.

title: So many better robots out there for the same money.
text: I want to give it higher marks because of the movie, but the wheels on the head were clogged and moving poorly within hours.  Its like a non-optical mouse but without the removable ring to clean the wheels.  There is no Amazon fire app for it, despite Amazon pushing it hard.  The messaging is absolute garbage.  The head keeps flying off and hitting the floor, maybe because the wheels are dirty.  The updates that come to my phone because my kids brand new Amazon pad, Ipad II, and LG phone have no compatible App, are advertising spam.  Like most of the Star wars stuff its overpriced garbage.  So it was good for about 2 hours of fun, followed by 2 hours of frustration and now sits on a 12 year olds shelf.

title: it is a nice ad, and it worked
text: My wife persuaded the purchase because she was taken by the presentation as seen in a bedbath&beyond store video ad in which they present the bb8 peeking round a corner as if peeking at you.  it is a nice ad, and it worked.  however, the way it is presented is naturally/reasonably interpreted that the device has awareness of that corner and an imperative to peek.  that is misrepresentation of the capabilities of the bb8.  I have yet to see what it learns, as is also promoted, and I checked some of the youtube reviews, post purchase arrggggh, and one extensive review of the disney, hasbro, and sphero bb8's function concur--not sure what this thing learns.  I know this from several hours experimenting, it does not learn where it is and more importantly where it has been.  it will continue to bang into to the same walls. it is essentially a brain-dead ball that moves about with a slick app that creates the illusion of an aware and interactive device. hohum.  that complaint is while on 'patrol.'  that is the reason I gave in to my wife--patrol curiosity.  patrol is a fail; it learns nothing and that is it.  the sounds come from the app, not the bb8.  you can assume some control of the device with 'drive' mode, but that function is not worth $150.  at that price range, I assumed more sophistication and higher age group target.  wrong.  my guess is with practice one can duplicate the peek with drive mode, but of course the reason my wife became smitten is defunct--back in the box.  this thing has a slick app, but the question after messing with it especially after the expectation dashed from the ad-high: what is it worth?  $49, maybe.  Continue to research the device prior to purchase--unlike this dumbbss contributor.  good luck.  I recommend waiting; it will not be too long before we have much more real (not fake) sophistication in these devices.  For those thinking I should have researched and had a better idea and it so unfair to not kissbss, I can argue the ad was my research.  not usually a good idea to base one's research solely on the manufacturer ad, but it is reasonable to assume what is seen is honestly presented.  They give idea this thing can navigate areas like it has awareness, no.  if it goes down a narrow corridor it is either in drive mode or getting lucky.  This thing is NOT worth $149.

title: My only gripe with the app so far is that i'd like to see them add new features (I suspect they're ...
text:
This is the droid you're looking for.

What's in the box:
BB-8 is packaged in a high quality box reminiscent of Sideshow collectibles packaging in terms of quality. Inside is a tray that holds the droid firmly still (It's unlikely they'll be found with scruffs or damaged antenna new out of the box, as it's packaged very well!). The box is so well done that I would have to say it is intended to be kept. Inside It has a charging base, cable for the base, warranty pamphlet, and BB-8.

BB-8 Sphero App
The app is similar in appearance and image quality to the new Star Wars app that has recently been put out. It is compatible with I-phones and Androids, so there's no need to worry about that, and it can work on tablets or phones. The app allows you to use augmented reality to play a short holomessage (Help me Obi-wan Kenobi, you're my only hope), remote control BB-8 with your tablet or cell phone, or wander mode, where the droid wanders on its own. There are several options for emoting the droid's action, such as nodding and disagreeing, babbling, and it can also be told to drive in a figure 8 or a square. Personally, I find just letting him wander to be most amusing. Sound comes out of your device speaker, not BB-8, which some may find disappointing. You can also adjust the max speed (and it's quite fast at top speed!). It have read something about voice activated commands, but I haven't seen that feature on my Samsung yet. Either I haven't found it, or it's not available on Android phones yet. My only gripe with the app so far is that i'd like to see them add new features (I suspect they're holding some back to avoid spoiling the movie), and an option to turn off the music. Music isn't too distracting though, as it only plays on the home screen and during start up.

Charger
The charger has to be plugged into a USB port, but if you have a USB to wall socket adapter you're good to go. If you set him to wander while he's on the base, he'll sit there and mumble at you. He moves around a bit while the app is on, as if he's contemplating his situation or what you're doing. When the app is off, he holds still and 'sleeps'.

BB-8 and general use
BB-8 itself is quite well done in appearance! The details are crisp, and his scale seems to be close to 1/6th scale. So if you never turned it on and just set it on a shelf with 1/6th scale sideshow star wars figures, he'd fit in quite well (and balances pretty good for a ball, too). The head is slightly smaller than as depicted in the movie, but it's not all that noticeable.

The droid is difficult to control via remote control, or at least, was for me. There's a blue light that shines through the sphere that you use your control to point toward yourself to orient the controls. Even still, so long as you are using it on the ground and not a table, it shouldn't be much of a problem while you're getting used to how it works. I have yet to have the head pop off in use even on wander mode (The droid detects collisions and rights itself when it bumps into something, even on wander mode ... after grumbling). It is rather small though, and at one point got behind my oven (it DID eventually find its own way out ... with a lot of complaints from BB-8). It doesn't see. When on wander mode it simply bumps into something, re-adjusts, and goes in a different direction.

It's quite solid, with the ball section of the droid being fairly heavy. The head his extremely light, and has no inner electronics. It seems to be controlled via magnets inside the body. My only worry about the robot over time is the detail on the sphere. I can see the paint eventually wearing with long term use over years. It's smooth as a cue ball with no sculpted detail, but looks great out of the box!

I would definitely not consider this a toy for a small kid. It's recommended for ages 8 and up, but it's honestly geared toward older people with disposable income. I could see an 8 to 11 year old screwing it up horribly, which would be ok if it weren't 150 dollars (which to me is a bit of cash).

Final thoughts:
I hope they update the app to disable music, and add pre-programmed movements and more sounds over time ... and want to see the voice activated commands implemented for android phones (assuming it's not just that I didn't find it on mine before writing the review). Outside of that, I'm happy with it. It's like having a small robot cat. ... I found myself talking to it at one point when it bumped into my feet. It really does seem to feel like it's got a personality, which is the big appeal of it. It's worth the price, but there's no need to buy from scalpers until it is out of production.

(I've included a picture of mine with a 1/6th sideshow real action hero R2-D2 for size comparison as to my basis as its estimated 1/6th scale).

title: Not as good as a real Sphero
text:
This is NOT compatible with the half-dozen Sphero "2.0" apps and a dozen more independently developed apps. The suite of Sphero 2.0 apps has all of the features that the BB8 app does and more - and this product can't access most of them.

Since it has "Sphero" in the name, I thought it would be a Sphero that was just superficially decorated like BB8. It's not. This is MUCH more limited than the Sphero 2.0. I am hugely disappointed.

Do yourself a favor and just buy a Sphero 2.0 and paint it. The cute little head isn't worth the crippling limitations of this product.

* EDIT: Originally, I said it was compatible with only one app. I've since learned that it's compatible with a handful of others, but my point still stands that this device is not compatible with *most* of the Sphero apps.

title: Best BB-8 toy Out There
text: I have seen Sphero before, so I knew what to expect size-wise. Two basic modes, Direct control and "roaming". The roaming is fairly entertaining, but it tends to get stuck it corners. It does not really track it's direction very well,  so when it gets stuck it has no real memory of the direction it came from. The controlled mode works great, and has a set of "reaction buttons". You can have BB-8 say yes, no, have a shocked, dumb founded and dizzy reaction. Once you get good at it you can make it have a whole conversation with someone. There is a voice control, but it is very limited to 4-5 reactions. They say it will possibly gain more capabilities in the future. One thing that would be nice is if could remember where it is and map out a room for the purpose of roaming. Manual and instructions are very limited, but most info can be found online searching in forums. If it blinks red, it either collided with something or the battery may be low.

title: So-So product...STELLAR customer service.
text: I purchased my BB-8 about 18 months ago. In many ways I was very happy with it, but in just as many ways I was disappointed. It is sturdily constructed, very cute, has a decent battery life and can be very amusing. It is also dependent upon an app to work, lousy on any carpet except for very short and tight knits or berber and difficult to control on hard floors, makes no sound (all sounds come from the app), and after a few uses gets kind of dull until a visitor comes to your house and wants a demo. The reason I gave it 4 stars has a lot to do with my experience with Sphero. After about 16 months it no longer held a charge. I contacted Sphero expecting nothing and was completely amazed by their customer service. I no longer had the box, proof of purchase, or receipt. It didn't matter. They had me take a photo of it next to my computer screen with google's search screen showing the date and time. The next day I had a prepaid fed ex label in my email to send my dead droid back to them and within 5 days I had a brand new one waiting at my door. I will never hesitate to purchase anything from Sphero (should something be of interest to me) , knowing that this company stands behind what they sell 100%.

title: The perfect gift for any Star Wars fan
text:
The title says it all, really. This little BB-8 (And I mean little, it stands at just a few inches) is an absolute blast to play with around the house.

It has quite a long battery life for its size with relatively quick charging considering it's contacless (Uses a dock that's powered through Micro-USB), and can traverse pretty rough terrain for it's size. With enough momentum, it'll easily get over most things scattered along the floor in the house, over the bumps in pavement and grass.

Hair and other kinds of fluff will often get caught in the wheels of BB-8's head, but it's nothing a tweezer can't fix. I've never had a problem with this before, as long as you regularly check to make sure there's no hair clogged up.

As BB-8 is connected through a smartphone, there's a whole variety of features to use. The most common and fun one is where you get to drive BB-8 around. There's another where you get to see BB-8 playing a video message through your phone, a 'roaming' mode where BB-8 will just roam about the room and learn where the obstacles are to avoid them (Does not work too well in complicated rooms with lots of obstacles), and even a mode where he'll sit down and watch Star Wars Episode 7 with you, reacting to all the different scenes in the movie. It's even possible to ask BB-8 a question, where he will then either shake or nod his head in response, as well as some audio feedback.

Though unfortunately the sound does not come from BB-8, it makes this device no less impressive.

If you, or anyone you know is an avid Star Wars fan, this is the perfect gift for them.

title: BB-Gr8
text:
This is a great droid and toy to play with. My dogs immediately went into "puppy mode" when seeing whirl itself around the living room. It's a little tricky to get the steering down at first but after about 5 minutes I had it down.

I was slightly disappointed that BB-8 doesn't actually have a type of AI that makes it aware of the surroundings when it goes into patrol mode.

The projection is a neat feature and cool to show off to friends and young ones. Especially because you can record a short clip using your camera and then BB-8 will display it in front of you on your phone screen. The only down side is that I REALLY wish you could post this records of BB-8 to social media because it would be neat to share the videos that way.

The battery life is pretty good if you ask me. The box advertises 60 minutes and I had it out for about 30-35 or so and I didn't notice any slowing down in movement. It does take about 3 hours to charge to full.

All in all I would give it 4 stars because it does feature a lot of cool things but it comes up slightly short in a couple areas.

Good job Sphero, and please release new software updates soon so we can hopefully record and upload our videos to social media.

title: and I'm pretty sure it was causing the head to continually fall ...
text:
It's all been said. I'll recap - overpriced, app is buggy, no holographic projection (the advertising sure leads you to believe that), there is no 'adaptive learning', charge doesn't last as long as advertised,.. and on and on. I found there was a circular piece of thin plastic on the bottom of the head designed to keep it clean during shipping... NO WHERE in the instructions is this mentioned, and I'm pretty sure it was causing the head to continually fall off.
Really, this is NOT the droid you're looking for... mine is going back...

title: Paper weight with no support from manufacturer.
text: I purchased this for my son. After a couple months, they updated the robot. It hasn't worked since. Try calling their tech support and you'll find there is no phone number. You only get email responses. They keep telling to try the same things over again, uninstall app and reinstall blah blah blah. For a toy that costs this much you'd think they'd do you the service of at least talking to you and making a real attempt to fix their piece of junk. Now it's an expensive decoration and I have to listen to my son complain about it. Thanks for nothing Sphero. Hope you enjoy my hard earned money!

title: More fun that you would think
text: I bought this droid for my 7 year old son.  When I got it out of the box and starting messing with it, I immediately ordered an R2-D2 to go with it.  They are a blast to play with.  We took them on vacation with us and used them there as well.  They are very detailed, easy to drive, and very robust.

title: but makes for great entertainment and as my hubby has been eying him ...
text: BB-8 is a little smaller and harder to steer than I thought he would be, but makes for great entertainment and as my hubby has been eying him up for over a year was definitely well worth it.  I got the Hermitshell protective case as well and it fits beautifully.  He does get caught in the furniture at times but I think this is mostly user inexperience.  His head does get knocked off occasionally but as it's magnetic, just clicks back on again.  It is a shame that the sound doesn't come out of the robot but as I was told by hubby, it wouldn't be waterproof if it had speakers in it.  The cat also loves watching BB-8 as he zips around the living room!

**BUYER BEWARE**
Shero discontinued the supporting app for this Droid rendering it completely useless. The fact this paperweight is being sold for more than it did at it's original launch is just extortion.
